We've seen some great wickets, if it is like that in October it will be a great World Cup to be part of and to learn."

 

Shubman Gill is the Player of the Match

Shubman Gill: "It feels good when you practice and it pays off. I was backing myself to score big. Happy to see it work out now. Everybody has a different technique to hit sixes. Hardik told me to play my game and he kept backing me. It was my dream to play for India, and I am very fortunate to be part of the team in all three formats."

 

Hardik Pandya is the Player of the Series:

Hardik Pandya, India Captain: "There were so many performances that were exceptional but happy to receive the Man of the Series. I always play the game like this, I try to read what is required, not have preconceived ideas. In my captaincy, I look to keep it simple and back my gut. I have a simple rule If I go down, I will go down on my terms. I wanted to make it a normal game because it was a decider. Hence, we batted first. Hopefully, we can continue performing like this."

Commentss: India Won by an innings and 132  Runs
TossDetails: Australia won the Toss and elected to bat
TossText: won the Toss and elected to bat
CompetitionName: Australia tour of India Test series 2022-23
Comments: India Won by an innings and 132  Runs
PreMatchCommentary:
Hello and welcome to the live commentary of the curtain raiser of the mightiest Border-Gavaskar Trophy which is played between the big guns India and Australia The Indian players are back in the whites for the red ball action for the next one month as the series comprises four Tests. There are many factors that make the clash epic but more importantly, the result of the series is vital for the teams to get into the final of the World Test Championship. There are many matchups to lookup for and it would be interesting to see who gets the better of against each other. What will be the first playing XI? Will India go with three spinners? Who will keep wickets for the match? Can India spin their way to victory or will the visitors open the series with a lead here? There is a lot to answer!

 

HEAD TO HEAD:-

The Indian team has an edge over the opposition with nine victories in 15 series. The home soil record for India hugely tilts towards the hosts with seven triumphs and Australia has only won one series in 2004. 

 

VENUE STATS:-

In six Tests played at Nagpur, the teams batting first have won three matches and the teams which bowl first have won twice. The average first innings score at the venue is 324 runs.

 

PITCH REPORT:- 

Sanjay Manjrekar and Matthew Hayden: "The soil looks pretty rough. There are cracks as well, and they may stay intact. But the real talking point is the rough area. left-hander against the left-arm spinner, it's going to be a nightmare for them because there is tremendous potential for the left-arm spinner. Check out the tone difference between here on a hard length for fast bowlers and on this danger area the spinning zone. You've got rough, you've got shaved grass, and it's ironic that the roller and the grass that was being cut here was just shavings of dust because it's going to be a turner."

 

TOSS:-

Pat Cummins calls right and Australia will Bat first! 

Pat Cummins, Australian Captain: "We will bat first. Looks like an even wicket in the middle. The preparation went really well in Bangalore. Can't wait. Two changes for us from the last game we played in Sydney. Todd Murphy debuts in place of Ashton Agar and Peter Handscomb comes in place of Travis Head."

 

Rohit Sharma, Indian Captain: "We would have batted too but hope we could restrict them as low as possible. Looks pretty dry and there will be help for spinners. We got to wait and see how much it does. We saw some seam movement for the pacers up front yesterday. We have had a good prep for the last 5-6 days. This is a big one. We know the importance of the series but we also understand it's about winning one session at a time. We have three spinners, and two-seamers with Bharat and Suryakumar Yadav making their debut."
PostMatchCommentary:
Day 1 : Australia- 177/10 (63.5 Overs, 2.8 rpo, 27x4, 0x6) || India- 77/1 (24 overs, 3.2 rpo, 10x4, 1x6)

Day 2 : India- 244/6 (90 overs, 2.7 rpo, 30x4, 2x6)

Day 3 : India- 79/3 (25.3 Overs, 3.1 rpo, 4x4, 4x6) || Australia - 91/10 (32.3 Overs, 2.8 rpo, 13x4, 1x6)

 

India takes a 1-0 lead in the series after an innings victory here in the first test at Nagpur by 132 runs. After opting to bat first, Australia lost both their openers early in the first session to the Indian seamers and then Jadeja starred with the ball, picking up 5 wickets in his comeback, helping India restrict Australia to 177 inside the first day - the visitors lowest total in the 1st innings since 2020. On the second day, Rohit Sharma led from the front and scored a hard-fought century, becoming the first Indian captain to score a century in all the formats, after which 50s from Ravindra Jadeja and Axar Patel helped India take a huge 1st innings lead of 223 runs. Ashwin took center stage in the 2nd innings, picking up his 31st 5-wkt haul in Tests, bowling out Australia for 91, helping India inch one step closer to the coveted WTC Final. Join us on Friday 17th Feb for the second test of the series!

 

Pat Cummins, Australia skipper: "The game moves pretty quickly here in India. The Indian spinners are always going to be hard work when it's spinning and Rohit played very well. The wicket spun in the first innings but it wasn't unplayable. We were 100 runs short. Starting here is tough but 3-4 of our guys got in. When you do get in, you got to score big scores."

 

Rohit Sharma, India Skipper: "Very important to start the series with a win. Happy that I could put the performance for the team, happy to be back. Since I was appointed Test captain, had played just two Tests and was ready for this one. In the last few years, with the kind of pitches we are playing in India, you need to have application and some sort of plan to score runs. I've grown up playing a lot in Mumbai on surfaces that turn a lot. Need to put pressure on bowlers as well by doing something different. We know we have quality in our spin department. But the seamers can be threatening as well on a pitch like that."

 

Ravindra Jadeja is the Player of the Match

Ravindra Jadeja: "Feels amazing, when you come back after five months and give your 100 percent, scoring runs and taking wickets. Was working hard at the NCA and would like to thank the NCA staff, and physios. They have been working hard with me, even on Sundays. Ball was spinning, going straight, keeping low and I kept telling myself to bowl at the stumps. I look to keep things simple and try not to change things with my batting."

TossDetails: Australia won the Toss and elected to bat
TossText: won the Toss and elected to bat
CompetitionName: Australia tour of India Test series 2022-23
PreMatchCommentary:
Hello and welcome to the live commentary of the second Test of the Border Gavaskar Trophy where the big guns India and Australia are clashing against each other at Arun Jaitley Stadium, Delhi. India wrapped up the first Test within two and a half days and claimed victory by an innings and 132 runs. Shreyas Iyer is back in the squad for India and will he replace someone straightaway? For Australia, Mitchell Starc is available, and if he plays who will be kept out to make him play? We have a landmark Alert also where Cheteshwar Pujara is all set to play his 100th Test! Can India turn the result on their way and lead the series or will the Australian team bounce back here? Will the Test go on till the fifth day? There is a lot to answer and let us await an interesting contest!

 

VENUE STATS:-

A total of 34 Tests has been played here by India at this stadium of which 13 have been won, 15 being drawn and 6 being lost. Since 1988, India has not lost a Test match here and it won't be too much if we say this is the Fortress for India. The Average first innings score here is 342 runs. Since 2011, the teams batting first have won 1 match and the teams bowling first have been victorious twice with the result being ended on a draw once.

 

PITCH REPORT: 

Sanjay Manjrekar and Matthew Hayden: "The pitch looks better than the first Test. It is a two-faced pitch that looks good in the center but changes as you come closer to the stumps, that's where the spinners will be effective. It looks like a Day 3 wicket right now with big cracks already. Though the groundsmen say it is unlikely to break up. It is a very dry wicket, so seamers may come into the play early. Pretty good for batting first on Day one."

 

TOSS:-

"Tails" call from Pat Cummins and Tails it is! Australia will Bat first!

 

Pat Cummins, Australian Skipper: "We are going to bat first and want to put runs on the board. The middle pitch looks like there's grass but it is bare at both ends. Plenty of turn there, will be a good Test. Cameron Green and Mitch Starc aren't playing. Travis Head comes in for Renshaw, and Matthew Kuhnemann makes his debut in place of Scott Boland."

 

Rohit Sharma, Indian Skipper: "We wanted to bat first as well. The pitch is dry. You just have to come out and play good cricket, and that has been the chat in the group. We are all thrilled about Pujara's 100th Test and it isn't easy. We have a change as Shreyas Iyer replaces Suryakumar Yadav."
PostMatchCommentary:
Day 1: Australia- 263/10 (78.4 Overs, 3.3 rpo, 34x4, 4x6) || India- 21/0 (9 overs, 2.3 rpo, 1x4, 0x6)

Day 2: India- 241/10 (74.3 Overs, 3.2 rpo, 24x4, 4x6) || Australia- 61/1 (12 overs, 5.1 rpo, 9x4, 1x6)

Day 3: Australia- 52/9 (19.1 Overs, 2.7 rpo, 6x4, 0x6) || India- 118/4 (26.4 overs, 4.4 rpo, 14x4, 4x6)

 

India wins the second match quite easily by 6 wickets and leads the four-match series 2-0! To begin with the toss, Australia once again won and elected to bat first. M Shami who ended up picking four wickets gave the initial breakthrough with the wicket of Warner after which the Aussie opener U Khawaja scored 81 runs as he stood in the crease till the 46th over. P Handscomb played a lonely knock of 72* runs in 142 balls. The Spinners Ashwin and Jadeja picked three wickets each and the opposition was all out for 263. The Indian team scored 262 runs and were bundled out in the second innings with the tail-end saviour show of Axar Patel (74 off 115)! Nathan Lyon was the highest wicket-taker with five wickets in this innings! When Australia came to bat, they were leading by a run. It was all the Spin show in the third innings with Jadeja accounting for 7 wickets which is his best figure to date. Apart from the double-digit scores of T Head and M Labuschagne, all the others were dismissed for a single-digit score. With 115 runs to chase, India lost a few wickets but it must be said that this is a comfortable win for the Indian boys!

 

Pat Cummins, Australian Skipper: "I thought 260 was a decent score in the first innings. The guys bounced back well. But India batted well. It was all even, in the innings break. We were ahead of the game but we slipped. We need a review of the shot choice and need to work in the room regarding it. Both games were disappointing but this one hurts more. We were ahead in the game and that doesn't happen often in India."

 

Rohit Sharma, India Skipper: "Fantastic result for us. The way we came back and finished our job was great. I think the bowlers were fantastic, to take 9 wickets today morning is commendable. And then we finished the job with the bat.  We were prepared for them to come out and play shots. Our idea was to not panic and just hit the right areas, waiting for the mistake to happen and that's exactly what happened. Our focus was keeping it tight in the morning, and these guys are the masters of bowling in these conditions. There are a lot of game-changing moments across four innings, but I thought the partnership between Jadeja and Virat and then Axar and Ash was brilliant."

 

Ravindra Jadeja is the Player of the Match

Ravindra Jadeja: "I was enjoying my bowling. These wickets suited me because the odd ball spins and some stayed low. I knew they would play sweeps and reverse sweeps, so my idea was just to keep it simple and straight to the stumps. I have a chance if they make mistakes."

TossDetails: India won the Toss and elected to bat
TossText: won the Toss and elected to bat
CompetitionName: Australia tour of India Test series 2022-23
PreMatchCommentary:
Hello and welcome to the live commentary of the Third Test of the Border Gavaskar Trophy where India and Australia are squaring off against each other at Holkar Cricket Stadium, Indore. India sealed the first two matches comfortably wrapping up the Test matches in just three days. The Australian team will miss their players Pat Cummins, David Warner, Josh Hazelwood, and Ashton Agar for the Test while the team will be led by Steve Smith. This is a must-win game for the visitors to at least take the series to the final Test - where if they win, then the series could be a tie with 2-2. But, will India allow the opposition to get the better of them or will they continue their supreme form? Cameron Green and Mitchel Starc will mostly be back in the action and what will be their playing combination here? Will India change their winning combination or will they continue with the same XI?  

 

VENUE STATS:-

Since 2016, two Tests have been played here and both the times, the teams who have won the toss decided to bat first and the results ended equal with one by batting first and one by bowling first. 

Average Scores by innings:

1st innings - 354

2nd innings - 396

3rd innings - 215

Only domestic multi-day matches were held here recently (Since 2022) and the teams winning the toss have opted to bat first 4 out of the 7 matches. The results stand as Bat First - 4 victories, Bat Second - 2 wins, and Draw - 1.

So shall we expect the team to win the toss and bat first?

 

PITCH REPORT: 

Murali Karthik and Matthew Hayden: "It is a very good wicket to bat on historically. It has small boundaries and the outfield is lightning fast. This wicket looks similar to the ones we saw in the first two Test matches. We are going to see lots of spin as it is dry. Bat first if you win the toss."

 

TOSS:-

Rohit wins the toss for the first time in the series and elects to bat first!

 

Rohit Sharma, Indian Skipper: "We will bat first. It is a pretty good dressing room and morale is high. The guys are confident about their skills which is a good thing moving forward. We have played a lot of cricket here but this one is slightly different. Looks a little dry and you have to adapt your skills and be at it all the time. We have to try and repeat the things we did in the first two Tests. A couple of changes as Gill replaces KL and Umesh gets a chance in place of Shami."

 

Steve Smith, Australian Skipper: "The surface looks pretty dry, and no surprises to bat first. Hopefully, we can execute our skills early and put the Indian batters under pressure. The guys have had time to rest and get back into preparation and it was most needed. Just stick to our methods for longer periods, we went away from it, especially in the second innings of the last game. We have two changes Starc comes in for Cummins and Cameron Green comes in for Warner."
PostMatchCommentary:
Day 1: India- 109/10 (33.2 Overs, 3.3 rpo, 11x4, 3x6) || Australia- 156/4 (54 overs, 2.8 rpo, 10x4, 0x6)

Day 2: Australia- 41/6 (22.3 Overs, 1.8 rpo, 4x4, 0x6) || India- 163/10 (60.3 overs, 2.7 rpo, 12x4, 4x6)

Day3: Australia- 78/1 (18.5 Overs, 4.1 rpo, 12x4, 1x6)

 

After two consecutive losses, Australia have made a comeback here by winning the third match of the series by 9 wickets. India for the first time here, won the toss and elected to bat first. The ball was turning well and the spinners were into play straight away. Apart from Kohli, no one scored more than 22 runs in the first innings and India was all out for 109. The spinners took all the wickets with M Kuhnemann grabbing a five-wicket haul. In the second innings, Australia scored 197 runs with U Khawaja scoring 60 with M Labuschagne getting 31. R Jadeja was the highest wicket-taker in the innings with four wickets. India trailed by 84 runs and Pujara's 59 helped the team to get a lead of 75 runs. Lyon recorded one of his best figures of 8/64. With 76 runs to chase, Travis Head (49* off 53) and M Labuschagne (28* off 58) took the team over the line. The next Test is scheduled at Ahmedabad on Mar 9th. Will Australia win and level the series or will the Indians get the better of the opposition on a crucial decider?

 

Rohit Sharma, Indian Captain: "When you lose a Test match there are a lot of things which didn't go our way. We didn't bat really well in the first innings and we understand how important it is to put runs on the board. Once they got an 80-90 run lead, we had to produce another innings with the bat and we were not able to do that. If we had batted well in the first innings then things would have been different. We need to understand we have to come out and do the job, no matter what the pitches are. One odd game can happen like that and this game was all about that. We want a few guys to stand up and put their hands up to take the team through."

 

Steve Smith, Australian Captain: "I think that first day, losing the toss and having to bowl first helped us get this result. Our bowlers did really well, especially Kuhnemann. With the bat, Khawaja was really good in the first innings. We had some good partnerships. India bowled really well in the second innings. Pujji played a good knock, but all our bowlers did really well. It was a complete performance in the end. I like captaining in this part of the world. It's good to be in the WTC final but it's just about playing good cricket."

 

Nathan Lyon is the Player of the Match

Nathan Lyon: "It has been a remarkable Test series. It is special to perform here. I don't have all the skills but I have the stock ball and try to do it well over and over again. I have been lucky enough to challenge the very best players in the game someone like Virat and Pujara."

TossDetails: Australia won the Toss and elected to bat
TossText: won the Toss and elected to bat
CompetitionName: Australia tour of India Test series 2022-23
PreMatchCommentary:
Hello and welcome to the live coverage of the 4th and final test of the Border Gavaskar Series 2023. The action shifts to the majestic Narendra Modi Stadium in Ahmedabad, with India needing a win to seal a place in the World Test Championship Final. The Men in Blue have won 15 consecutive home series and will look to make it 16 after this test. The Prime Ministers of both nations are also in attendance for the first day.

 

VENUE REPORT:-

India had won the two Tests played at the venue in 2021 against England, with the spinners picking up 48 wickets. Will we see spin dominating again in this test?

 

Teams have preferred batting 1st at Ahmedabad with both the tests in 2021 seeing the teams choosing to bat first, and the same trend seems to continue in the Ranji Trophy this season as well with teams choosing to bat first in 4/5 matches.

Pitch Report, Matthew Hayden: "The pitch looks different to the one used against England. It looks well rolled, there is an even covering of grass and there are a few dry patches on the surface. Looks slightly damp as well in the morning. The spinners have loved to operate in these conditions and there will be plenty of wickets in it for the spinners."

 

TOSS:-
 

Steve Smith calls right at the toss and Australia have elected to bat first.

 

Steve Smith, Australia Captain: "We are going to bat. Looks like a good wicket. The guys performed well last week and we are playing with the same team."

 

Rohit Sharma, Indian Captain: "We would have batted first also. Siraj is rested and Shami is back. It's always nice to have some time off. We need to regroup as a team, you can reflect on so many things. Not the surface what we saw in the first three Tests, looks a good pitch, I hope it stays the same for all five days."
PostMatchCommentary:
Day 1: Australia- 255/4 (90 overs, 2.8 rpo, 36x4, 0x6)

Day 2: Australia- 225/6 (77.2 overs, 2.9 rpo, 27x4, 0x6) || India- 36/0 (10 overs, 3.6 rpo, 3x4, 1x6)

Day 3: India- 253/3 (89 overs, 2.8 rpo, 20x4, 2x6)

Day 4: India- 282/6 (79.5 overs, 3.5 rpo, 20x4, 7x6) || Australia- 3/0 (6 overs, 0.5 rpo, 0x4, 0x6)

Day 5: Australia- 172/2 (72.1 overs, 2.4 rpo, 20x4, 2x6)

 

A draw was always on the cards after the two sides put up huge first innings totals on the board. Aussies managed to score 480 with the help of tons from Usman Khawaja and Cameron Green while R. Ashwin was the pick of the bowlers accounting for 6 wickets.On the other side India's response was led by King Kohli who amassed 186 and Shubman Gill who made 128. A solid reply of 571 from India meant that the Aussies had the task of surpassing the lead of 91 before setting a target for the home team. Australia in the end managed to bat the entire fifth day scoring 175 and losing just two wickets. Aussies fought bravely but fell short to breach the fortress and win the series against India in India. Team India win the series 2-1 and also Keep the Border Gavaskar Trophy home. The two teams are the best in the World and will compete once again in June for the World Test Championship at the Oval. 

 

Virat Kohli is the Player of the Match

 

Virat Kohli: "To be honest, the expectations I have from myself as a player matters more to me. I felt I was batting well from the first innings at Nagpur and carried the form in the innings that followed. We focussed on batting for longer durations. I did that to an extent but not to the capability that I have done in the past so I Was a little disappointed with that. Relief from the point of view that I could play the way I wanted to play and get a hundred."

 

Steve Smith, Australia skipper: "Was a flat track at the back end but the boys had a great time throughout. The hospitality has been amazing in India, the crowd has been amazing as always. We started to play better as the series went on. The madness and errors in one hour in Delhi cost us that game and that was a crucial moment in the series too. The wicket here was too flat for us to force a result with the time remaining. The spinners bowled really well in the series. Todd Murphy and  Matt Kuhnemann bowled with composure alongside Natham Lyon, pretty happy to see them do well."

 

Ravi Ashwin and Ravindra Jadeja share the Player of the Series Award!

Ravi Ashwin: "It has been a great journey alongside Ravindra Jadeja. We go back a long way but we wouldn't be the same or lethal enough without the other. We need to recognize that fact, at least I have started recognizing that over the last couple of years. He gives me a lot of freedom to be creative with the ball, full credit to him, I thought he bowled beautifully in the Delhi Test and that's why we are here today in such a position. Jaddu keeps it really simple and that reflects in his performances"

 

Ravindra Jadeja: " It feels very good bowling with him. He is passing on vital information all the time. What field to have for a batter, how to bowl to a particular batter. About my batting, I missed out on a few occasions this series which I would want to work upon. I will work harder and focus on my batting even more."

 

Rohit Sharma, India Skipper: "Was a fantastic series overall. A lot of the players were playing this for the first time in their careers. We do understand the importance of this series and the capabilities of the opposition too. A lot of hard work has gone into this in terms of planning and preparations. At different times we have come up with answers to tough situations. We knew how important it was to start the series on a positive note. The Delhi Test, I am very proud of as we were behind in the game and came back. At Indore, it did not go our way. Lot of guys took up the responsibility and bailed us out when the team needed the most. Test Cricket is hard-fought cricket and isn't easy at any point. I am quite satisfied with how the team has done. I know what kind of benchmark I have set for myself. I keep the personal milestones aside, We have got the result of what I wanted from the series. To get the result makes us very happy."

TossDetails: India won the Toss and elected to Field
TossText: won the Toss and elected to Field
CompetitionName: Australia tour of India ODI series 2022-23
PreMatchCommentary:
Hello and welcome to the live coverage of the 1st of the three ODIs between India and Australia. The Men in the Blue head into the series on the back of the Test series victory and also qualifying for the WTC Final. It is a good opportunity for the Indian Unit to test its best combination before the upcoming ODI World Cup. Hardik Pandya will lead the side in absence of Rohit Sharma who will join in later in the series. India is currently the best team in the format while Australians are placed second in the ICC Men's ODI ranking. Steve Smith and co. will look to get some good practice in India which is also the host of the ODI World Cup. The Border Gavaskar Trophy was convincingly won by India, will Australia be able to get past the home team in the ODI format or the Men in Blue will have the upper hand once again? All in all, It will be an exciting contest between two star-studded sides at the Wankhede stadium in Mumbai. 

 

HEAD TO HEAD:-
India and Australia have clashed 143 times out of which Australians have clinched 80 games while India came out victorious on 43 occasions. 

 

PITCH REPORT: 
Murali Karthik and Ajit Agarkar: "I'm standing at the center pitch from where it is 64 meters to my right and 62 meters to my left. There is a nice even covering of grass, very firm, and will play well for the entire game. There should be some bounce and spinners may not be in the game. Wankhede is always a good chasing ground, especially with the boundary dimensions"

 

TOSS:-
Hardik Pandya wins the toss and elects to field first!

 

Hardik Pandya, India Skipper: "We'll field first. It looks like a good track and the dew will be a factor here. We feel we can do well while chasing.  Playing for India every game and every format is important for every player. Especially this being a World cup year, the ODI format is even more important. We've gone with four pacers - Shardul Thakur, Mohammad Shami, myself, and Mohammad Siraj. Two spinners in the side are Ravindra Jadeja and Kuldeep Yadav."

 

Steve Smith, Australian Skipper: "No worries, Good toss to lose actually. Happy batting first because I was unsure what to do. We got to try and test our best to adjust to Indian conditions, and get our combinations right before the important WC2023.
PostMatchCommentary:
Powerplay (1-10 Overs) :-

Australia- 59/1 (5.9 rpo, 10x4, 1x6) || India- 39/3 (3.9 rpo, 6x4, 0x6)

Middle Overs (11-40 Overs) :- 

Australia- 129/9 (5.1 rpo, 10x4, 5x6) || India- 152/2 (5.1 rpo, 13x4, 2x6)

 

Australia put up a below-average score of 188 after being sent into bat. Indian bowlers kept picking wickets from one end while Mitchell Marsh seemed like batting on a different track altogether. Marsh smashed 81 of 65 balls before falling to Ravindra Jadeja. It was Mohammad Shami who ran through the middle order picking up 3 wickets in no time. Australia lost their last 8 wickets for just 59 runs. India in response lost four wickets for just 39 on board after which Hardik Pandya and KL Rahul put up a 44-run stand off just 55 balls to get India back in the game. But it was the unbeaten partnership of 108 of 123 balls between KL Rahul and Ravindra Jadeja that took India Home with a little 10 overs to spare. Rahul was the top scorer with 75* while the left-handed Jadeja finished unbeaten on 45. India will look to win the next game at Vishakhapatnam and seal the three-game series. 

 

Steve Smith, Australian Captain: "We weren't expecting this to happen at the Wankhede, usually pretty good wicket to score runs. India did bowl well. But we missed out too. If we had got something over 250, it would have been interesting looking at the way the ball was swinging and seaming throughout the innings. KL Rahul and Ravindra Jadeja played well to take India out of trouble and win it from there".

 

Hardik Pandya, Indian Captain: "We were under pressure but we kept our composure and found ways to come out of those difficult situations. Once we got the momentum, we were quite on top of the game. Jaddu was outstanding and did what is exactly expected of him considering the capabilities he possesses. KL was brilliant and it's good to see him play in the manner he is most comfortable in. "

 

Ravindra Jadeja is the Player of the Match

"I’m playing ODI after 8 months so was just looking to adjust at the earliest. Luckily did well with the ball and with the ball got three wickets too. My main goal was to build a partnership alongside KL and that happened today so, very pleased with the overall outcome."

GroundName: Dr YS Rajasekhara Reddy ACA-VDCA Cricket Stadium
TossDetails: Australia won the Toss and elected to Field
TossText: won the Toss and elected to Field
CompetitionName: Australia tour of India ODI series 2022-23
PreMatchCommentary:
Hello and welcome to the live commentary of the 2nd ODI between two of the biggest cricketing nations, India and Australia at the Dr. Y.S. Rajasekhara Reddy ACA-VDCA Cricket Stadium, Visakhapatnam. India came out victorious in a low scoring encounter at Mumbai, where KL Rahul and Jadeja batted with utmost composure to take India home with an unbeaten century partnership. With Rohit Sharma coming back into the mix, India would be hoping to seal the series. Ishan Kishan is expected to make place for Rohit in this match and also KL Rahul coming back to form is a big plus for India keeping in mind that the world cup is just a few months away. As for Australia, Alex Carey who was out of the mix in the 1st ODI due to illness is expected to return for this encounter. About David Warner, we will have to wait and watch for if he has recovered from the concussion and if he will be available for selection. Let's head into this cracker of a contest and see what's waiting ahead for us.

 

HEAD TO HEAD :-
India and Australia have squared off 144 times and Australia has the upper hand with 80 wins and India winning 54 of those. Whereas, India have the upper hand in India winning 39 matches and Australia winning 30.

 

PITCH REPORT: 
Deep Das Gupta: "The pitch was under covers just an hour back and there were hints of slight drizzle but look at it now, the covers are off, and it's bright and sunny. The pitch looks firm and it doesn't look like that the cracks will open up soon. There will be some moisture as the pitch has been under covers for the last couple days. Batting would get easier as the day progresses. The toss winning captain should prefer bowling first."

 

TOSS:-
Steve Smith and Australia win the toss and elect to field first!

 

Steve Smith, Australian Skipper: "We will bowl first. This is a different wicket and it has been under covers for a while. We learn a lot from playing at these pitches. We have a couple of changes, Nathan Ellis comes in for Maxwell who is a bit sore and Alex Carey comes in for Josh Inglis." 

 

Rohit Sharma, India Skipper: "Doesn't really matter now (Laughs on asking what he would have done if he had won the toss). We have to bat well and let's see where we end up after the 1st innings. Every game is a pressure game when you play for India. Two changes for us too, Ishan misses out and I am back for him. Shardul is also out and Axar replaces him. We would have bowled first if we had won the toss, given that we have 3 spinners and playing 3 spinners is also something we might go into the world cup with."
PostMatchCommentary:
Powerplay (1-10 Overs) :-

India- 51/5 (5.1 rpo, 6x4, 0x6)  || Australia- 112/0 (11.2 rpo, 15x4, 6x6)

Middle Overs (11-26 Overs) :- 

India- 66/5 (4.1 rpo, 3x4, 2x6)

 

Australian Team after suffering a defeat in the first ODI came back in some fashion getting the Indian team all out for just 117 after asking them to bat first. The opening Spell from Mitchell Starc proved to be lethal as he managed to get four out of the top five wickets with just 48 runs on board. Only Virat Kohli and Axar Patel got decent starts but failed to convert the same into big scores. Mitchell Starc's fifer was well-complimented by Ellis and Abbott from the other end. In Response, The Australian openers Mitch Marsh and Travis Head came out all guns blazing and finished the run chase in just 11 overs. The series is well poised after this dominating effort from the Australian Unit especially after suffering a heavy loss in the series opener at Wankhede. We will now move on to Chennai for the series decider.

 

Rohit Sharma, Indian Captain: "It was not a 117 wicket by any means. We did not apply ourselves and play well. We did manage some runs in the middle but again failed to make big partnerships as we kept losing wickets at regular intervals. It was one of those days when nothing goes your way. Taking nothing away from the Aussies, Starc did what he has been doing for the team. Mitchell Marsh is one of the top batters when it comes to power hitting and we saw that in the first ODI too. It is important for us to move on from this and bounce back."

 

Steve Smith, Australian Captain: "Was a quick one today. Only 37 overs in the entire game. Mitch Starc was brilliant with the new ball which put them under pressure straight away. There was no total in mind for restricting the Indians just that we need to stick to our plans. We were just trying to execute our plans. Just that kind of a day when the edges went to hand and we managed to hold onto them. The way Travis Head and Mitch Marsh played at the start was phenomenal. They just kept going at a good rate and we are able to bounce back after the loss in the last game".

 

Mitchell Starc is the Player of the Match. 

Mitchell Starc: "I have learned the trade over the years and am now able to do it regularly. My rhythm has been good lately. My length is a little fuller than before and in comparison to other guys in the team. I have been given a definite role in the team and I stick to that. My conversations are a little different compared to someone like Cameron Green or Sean Abbott. The tracks in both games have assisted the seamers, especially with the breeze going around. My role is to attack stumps and get early dismissals and I am happy that I have been able to do that for the side"

TossDetails: Australia won the Toss and elected to bat
TossText: won the Toss and elected to bat
CompetitionName: Australia tour of India ODI series 2022-23
PreMatchCommentary:
Hello and welcome to the Live commentary of match three of the ODI series between India and Australia. The series decider will take place at MA Chidambaram Stadium, Chennai. The first ODI at Wankheded was dominated by the Indian Team whereas Australia got the better of the hosts at Vizag in the previous game. The final will answer a lot of questions about the two teams in terms of their squad and playing combination for the upcoming ODI World cup which is going to take place in India. The series has so far seen the pace bowlers having a treat in the middle as both the matches ended as low-scoring encounters. One can expect slightly different conditions in spin-friendly conditions in Chennai. Australian seamers seem to have got the rhythm while Travis Head and Mitchell Marsh have been instrumental with the bat for the Aussies. One can expect a change in the batting order if David Warner recovers from his injury sustained during the BGT Series. India on the other side will look to give another opportunity to the eleven that featured in the previous games. It will be a cracker of a contest at an expected full house at the Chidambaram Stadium, Chennai!

 

PITCH REPORT: 
Sanjay Manjrekar and Ajit Agarkar: "Pitch is slightly off-center, so the dimensions change a little and it's going to be a long boundary on one side. As we have seen the Bowlers have had a little bit of help throughout the series. This track too has a covering of grass and also has rough in the center. It's quite hard and the roughness might be a factor in the first innings. It might be slightly two-paced initially in the game. Teams winning the toss will like to bowl first as it gets cooler it turns into a belter to bat."

 

Head to Head:
Two teams have clashed 145 times out of which 54 have been won by India while 81 results have gone to the Aussies.

 

TOSS:-
Australia wins the toss and elects to bat first!

 

Steve Smith, Australian Skipper: "We are gonna have a bat. Looks like a very dry surface and it is pretty hot out here as well. Will look to put some runs on this surface and defend later on. We have had good fun in the series which has been very competitive and it will be exciting in the decider today. We love playing in the crunch games and it's exciting for us to come  out and put upna show. Ashton Agar and David Warner comes in to the side. Cameron Green sits out due to bad health.

 

Rohit Sharma, India Skipper: "We were looking to field first. If at all there will be help for the bowlers and we are playing three spinners today like last game, in these dry conditions hopefully we can maximize our spin options. It's an important game and finals are always exciting. It's always good to be in such situations. It's a challenge for us to come back after what happened in the last game and play some good cricket under pressure when it matters the most. Hopefully, we can put our best foot forward and win the series"
PostMatchCommentary:
Powerplay (1-10 Overs) :-

Australia- 61/0 (6.1 rpo, 9x4, 3x6)  || India- 67/1 (6.7 rpo, 6x4, 3x6)

Middle Overs (11-40 Overs) :- 

Australia- 148/7 (4.9 rpo, 10x4, 2x6)  || India- 137/5 (4.5 rpo, 8x4, 3x6)

Death Overs (41-50 Overs) :- 

Australia- 60/3 (6.6 rpo, 3x4, 3x6)   || India- 44/4 (4.8 rpo, 1x4, 1x6)

 

It was Australia's call to bat first after winning the toss. Head and Marsh were once again successful to get Australia off to a good start but the middle order once again failed to have a major impact. Aussies managed to put up 269 runs on the board with Marsh being the top scorer with 47 against his name. Hardik Pandya was the pick of the bowlers with 3 wickets to his credit while Jadeja bowled economically conceding just 34 from his 10 overs. In reply, India got a good start courtesy of Rohit Sharma and Shubman Gill who added 65 for the first wicket. Kohli and KL Rahul too got a good partnership between them but could not capitalize on it. India kept losing wickets and the Aussies managed to put breaks on the scoring rate which ultimately resulted in India falling short by 21 runs. Adam Zampa picked four scalps and was impressed with the way he operated. Australia fought well and came out victorious against India on Indian soil which deserves a round of applause. All in all, it was a hard-fought series between the top two sides in World Cricket at the moment. 

 

Rohit Sharma, India Skipper: "I don't think it was too many runs on the board. We didn't bat well, to be honest. Partnerships are crucial while chasing and that is something we failed to do in this game. We know the wickets well and it's important you apply yourself while you're in the middle. After the start, it was important for one batter to carry on and take the game deep. It just didn't happen today. We can take a lot of positives from the nine ODIs since January. We need to understand where we need to improve and execute accordingly."

 

Steve Smith, Australian Skipper: "It's been an enjoyable tour overall. I would say We didn't play our best cricket, good enough to get over the line though. This wicket was entirely different today, we left a few out there with the bat and could have got more. But the spinners bowled beautifully, with really good performances from Zampa and Agar. It was a grind to get the India batters out from the moment when they were cruising along. Happy with the way things have gone."

 

Adam Zampa is the Player of the Match

 

Adam Zampa: "Yes, I have had some success here. It's a tough place to come and deliver, always a huge challenge when you're playing in India against India. I try to stay in the game and be competitive always. Ashton Agar changed the game today and helped me with my spell too. Kudos to the bowlers who bowled before me as they set the tone really well for me. "
 

Mitchelle Marsh is the player of series
Mitchelle Marsh: "There is this Natural aggression when it comes to batting. It's been a lot of fun while opening the innings. We have Warner who'll come back at some stage and open the innings. About me, I'm coming off an extended break and have worked on a lot of things. Came here really fresh for the series and glad that I could deliver.

TossDetails: India won the Toss and elected to Field
TossText: won the Toss and elected to Field
CompetitionName: ICC WORLD TEST CHAMPIONSHIP FINAL 2023
PreMatchCommentary:
Hello and a warm welcome to cricket fans from all over the World for the live commentary of the Ultimate Championship  between India and Australia. We are back here at the Kennington Oval, London for the Red ball action after a few months. This is the ultimate battle after a long war that has been taking place for the past two years. Multiple nations faced each other and the two teams which turned out best are Australia and India. This is the second edition of the World Test Championship and India gets through for the second time successively. Will India make the qualification worth it unlike the last time or will the Australians dominate here in England? Can the Indians create history? How will the playing combination be for India? Will they go with four pacers or will it be two spinners? Let's wait and watch and hope this encounter turns out to be an exciting one!

 

HEAD TO HEAD:-
India and Australia have faced each other 106 times and the opposition has an edge over India with 44 victories and India with 32. The last time these two oppositions faced were a couple of months back in India for a Four-Test match series where the Indians won the series 2-1.

 

                                                                                           


VENUE STATS:
Last 10 MATCHES IN OVAL: 
WON  FIRST: 5
WON  SECOND: 4

The average 1st innings score here is 312 runs.

 

                                                                                                  


Pitch Report:
Kumar Sangakkara: "It's cold here and there's a bit of wind. It's overcast as well so we can expect swing early on. When we look closer at the pitch, there's a lovely green covering of grass, so there'll be seam as well. We can expect a very good bounce here. So the teams might win the toss and opt to bowl?


TOSS:-
India wins the toss and elects to  first!

 

Rohit Sharma,  Skipper: "We will bowl first as the conditions and also the weather is overcast. The pitch won't change too much. We are going with four seamers and one spinner - Jadeja. It's always tough to leave Ashwin as he has been a match-winner for us over the years."

 

                                                                                                      


Pat Cummins,  Skipper: "We would have bowled as well. Hopefully, there will be a spin on days four and five. We've been here for about 10 days. Pretty fresh, the weather has been nice, and we haven't missed a session, feeling good. Boland makes it into the playing XI and this pitch will suit him very well and he could be a serious weapon for us"
PostMatchCommentary:
Day 1: Australia- 327/3 (85 Overs, 3.9 rpo, 47x4, 1x6)

Day 2: Australia- 142/7 (36.3 Overs, 3.9 rpo, 17x4, 1x6) || India- 151/5 (38 overs, 3.97 rpo, 19x4, 1x6)

Day 3: India- 145/5 (31.4 Overs, 4.6 rpo, 16x4, 1x6) || Australia- 123/4 (44 Overs, 2.8 rpo, 10x4, 2x6)

Day 4: Australia- 147/4 dec (40.3 Overs, 3.6 rpo, 19x4, 0x6) || India- 164/3 (40 overs, 4.1 rpo, 24x4, 1x6)

Day 5: India- 70/7 (23.3 overs, 3.0 rpo, 9x4, 0x6)


The ICC World Test Championship cycle has come to an end with Australia becoming the Ultimate Champions. Both the teams worked really hard and showed great agility for a long time and that is the reason for both the teams to get into the biggest stage of the longest format. However, Australia were better in this given Test and bagged the match by 209 runs. The toss favored the Indians and they chose to bowl first considering the conditions. The centuries from Steve Smith and Travis Head set the tone for a huge total and the team registered 469 runs. M Siraj was the highest wicket-taker for India with 4 scalps. After picking a few early wickets in the 1st Indian innings, the partnership of 109-run between Ajinkya Rahane and Shardul Thakur helped the team avoid the follow-on! With a lead of 173 runs on day 3, Australia were to set an unachievable target for India. Alex Carey's 66 runs were the highest from their batting and they declared after setting 444 runs. With a huge target to chase which would have been turned as the World record, the Indian batters Rohit Sharma and Shubman Gill started off with positive intentions but unfortunately, Gill was turned out. Hope was there until Virat Kohli and Ajinkya Rahane battled through but wickets fell in regular intervals and were all out for 234 runs with Nathan Lyon taking 4 and Boland taking 3 crucial wickets. 


Travis Head is the Player of the Match

Travis Head: "We put in a lot of hard work over the two years. We have always had a positive approach with the bat. Amazing Test from Smith and what we've come to expect from him here in England. Hope it's a big couple of months from him. I've always had the confidence and It's about going out there and expressing that. I've always been open to learning. I've bedded down somewhat of a blueprint. It's not always going to work. It's nice to work that out in such a big game and hopefully continues in the next couple of months."


Rohit Sharma, Indian Skipper: "I thought we started well putting them to bat in those conditions. We bowled well in the first session and then we let ourselves down. Got to give credit to the Australian batters. Head came in and played really well along with Smith. That just took us off guard a little bit. We knew it was always hard to come back, but we put up a good show. We fought till the end. We've worked hard for all those four years. Playing two finals is honestly a good achievement for us. But we'd like to go a mile ahead as well. Unfortunate that we couldn't go on and win the final but we'll keep our heads high and fight. The cheer from the crowd has been brilliant."


Pat Cummins, Australian Skipper: "We made the most of it after losing the toss. We also wanted to bowl. The way Head and Smith put on that partnership, gave us the comfort. Head has been brilliant right throughout this campaign. We left day one feeling like we were on top of the game. When it counted, we played really well. We could have really driven the game, didn't have our best day, and let India closer back in. For the most part, we were in control. Everyone played really well and we'll savour this for a few years. This is our favourite format, we grew up watching Test cricket. It challenges you. When you win, it's the format you get most satisfaction with."

Commentss: India Won by an innings and 141  Runs
TossDetails: West Indies won the Toss and elected to bat
TossText: won the Toss and elected to bat
CompetitionName: India Tour of West Indies Test Series 2023
Comments: India Won by an innings and 141  Runs
PreMatchCommentary:
Hello and a warm welcome to the audience of Test cricket as the Indian team is all set to face the WIndies after a small break since the World Test Championship last month. India are here at Dominica after 2011 and Virat Kohli was the only player who played last here in the current squad. West Indies previously played their Test against South Africa in March. We might get to see some new faces here for this Test as Y Jaiswal and I Kishan have been handed over the cap! Can they perform well on their debut?

 

HEAD TO HEAD:-

India and West Indies have squared off against each other 98 times in Test cricket and India has 22 games to their tally while the hosts West Indies lead the number with 30 wins. 46 matches have ended in a draw. However, India have won 4 out of their last 5 clashes.


VENUE STATS:-
A total of 5 Test matches have been played here since 2011 and the teams have opted to bowl first three times but the result have favoured the teams batting first thrice. The average innings scores here are 
1st Innings - 246
2nd Innings - 302
3rd Innings - 222

 

TOSS:-

West Indies won the toss and elected to bat first!


Kraigg Brathwaite, West Indies Skipper: "We will bat first. The surface is dry, we'll have to work hard in the first hour. We had a practice game amongst ourselves and was looking good. We have been in good positions during the last cycle, but it's all about being consistent. Want to see the guys be positive. Athanaze makes his debut. Cornwall and Warrican are the two spinners with Alzarri and Roach being the pacers."


Rohit Sharma, Indian Skipper: "We played a practice game in Barbados and we are here in Dominica for the last 4 days. Rain played a spoilsport but we are well prepared. The championship cycle final is two years away, but we've been consistent over the previous cycles. New guys in the squad, we just want to keep better as a team. I want the two debutants to enjoy, they've worked hard to come here, I want to make them feel comfortable and have some good memories of their first Test."
PostMatchCommentary:
Day 1: West Indies - 150/10 (64.3 overs, 2.3 rpo, 15x4, 1x6) || India - 80/0 (23 overs, 3.5 rpo, 9x4, 1x6)

Day 2: India - 232/2 (90 overs, 2.6 rpo, 17x4, 1x6)

Day 3: India - 109/3 (39.2 overs, 2.7 rpo, 9x4, 2x6) || West Indies - 130/10 (50.3 overs, 2.6 rpo, 13x4, 2x6)

 

A wonderful display of Test cricket from the Indian team as they start the next WTC cycle with a promising victory by 141 runs and innings! West Indies had the advantage with the toss and they chose to bat first at this wicket. Ravi Ashwin opened the account early in the innings and ended up picking 5 wickets. Apart from the local boy Alick Athanaze's 47, the WI batting collapsed for 150 runs. The Indian openers Jaiswal and Rohit partnered for 229 runs with each of them scoring centuries. Jaiswal later went on to convert his ton into 150 and got out for 171 runs. V Kohli at number four did his part by making 76 runs. 
With a lead of 271 runs, India declared the innings. R Ashwin once again proved why he is the No.1 Test bowler by taking a 7-wicket haul making his best overseas record with 11 wickets.  The WI team were all out for 130 runs and India sealed the match by 141 runs and innings!


Yashasvi Jaiswal is the Player of the Match

Yashasvi Jaiswal: " We prepared pretty well. Spoke a lot to Rahul Dravid sir and learned from him. Would like to thank all the selectors and Rohit sir for having faith in me. It's really nice, I have been working on this. Playing Test cricket for India is very special and emotional. This is just the start, I need to keep my focus and keep working on my cricket. Lots of people helped me through my journey and I want to thank each and every one of them."


Kraigg Brathwaite, West Indies Captian: "I want to thank the crowd for coming. The pitch was playing well on day one, we let ourselves down with the bat. It wasn't spinning a lot. It is my job to lead from the front but I couldn't get runs. We lost too many wickets in the first innings. You need to have the right balance between defending and trying to score. We didn't execute the shots we wanted to, and we need to learn to use the bat more. Athinaze had a very good start, the way he batted. He will do a lot for West Indies cricket."


Rohit Sharma, Indian Captain: "I would like to start by saying it was a great effort with the ball. Getting them out for 150 set the game for us. We knew batting would get tough, it wasn't easy to score runs. We knew we wanted to bat only once and bat long. Jaiswal has the talent, he has shown us in the past that he is ready. Both Ashwin and Jadeja were splendid, especially Ashwin for coming out and bowling this way was class. Always nice to start well, it is a fresh cycle. We weren't too worried about the pitch, we wanted to come here and get results. Important to start well, now about taking that momentum into the 2nd Test. There are a couple of new guys and people who haven't had much Test cricket, so just about getting them out on the field now."

TossDetails: West Indies won the Toss and elected to Field
TossText: won the Toss and elected to Field
CompetitionName: India Tour of West Indies Test Series 2023
PreMatchCommentary:
Hello and welcome to the live commentary of the second and final Test between West Indies and India at Queen's Park Oval, Port of Spain, Trinidad. India stamped the authority by winning the previous fixture by an innings and 141 runs. Y Jaiswal served a classy 171-run feast on his debut in the previous match and Ashwin was the star with the ball with 12 scalps. West Indies has named the Off-spinner K Sinclar for this Test and will he get his Test cap here while India may go with their same strong XI. Can India seal the series or will West Indies fight back today to nullify the series?

This is the 100th TEST between these two teams! Also, a special match for the Indian run-machine Virat Kohli as he is all set to play his 500th International game!

 

VENUE STATS:-
A total of 4 Test matches have been played here since 2012 and the teams have opted to bat first on all occasions. Once the teams batting first have won and once the team bowling first has won. The other two matches have ended in a draw. 

Average Scores by innings:
1st innings - 315
2nd innings - 301
3rd innings - 238


TOSS:-
West Indies opts to field first!


Kraigg Brathwaite, West Indies Captain: "We will bowl first. Shannon Gabriel is back on the team. McKenzie makes his debut today. There's some moisture on the pitch. We got to be mentally ready for the challenge as the first game is gone. We got to believe in ourselves. We came a long way, in the matches between India and West Indies. Recently we haven't won, looking to change it."

 

Rohit Sharma, India Skipper: "We wanted to bat first. Looks nice and sunny as well. It's going to get slower. Unfortunately, Shardul has pulled up a niggle and he's not fit. Mukesh Kumar has worked well in domestic and is going to make his debut. There are a lot of memories, the rivalry between the two teams has always been exciting to watch. We work hard and hopefully, we get the result we are expected of."
PostMatchCommentary:
Day 1: India - 288/4 (84 overs, 3.4 rpo, 32x4, 3x6) 

Day 2: India - 150/6 (44 overs, 3.4 rpo, 16x4, 0x6) || West Indies - 86/1 (41 overs, 2.1 rpo, 8x4, 1x6) 

Day 3:  West Indies - 143/4 (67 overs, 2.1 rpo, 11x4, 1x6) 

Day 4: West Indies - 26/5 (7.4 overs, 3.4 rpo, 3x4, 0x6) || India - 181/2 (24 overs, 7.5 rpo, 14x4, 6x6) || West Indies - 76/2 (32 overs, 2.4 rpo, 10x4, 0x6)

 

Rain played spoilsport on the 5th day and the match ends in a draw! The first match of the two-match series was won by India and hence the Indian team is the winner of the Test series.


West Indies won the toss and opted to field first. The opening partnership of 139 runs between Rohit (57 off 74) & Jaiswal (80 off 43) set the platform for a big total after which Virat Kohli pulled off his 76th International century with Jadeja who scored 61 runs. Ashwin in the end put up 56 runs to make the total 438. Apart from the West Indies Skipper who scored 75 runs, there was not much contribution from the other batters which led the team to score 255. Siraj accounted for 5 wickets in that innings. With a lead of 181 runs, the Indian batters fired quickly to score 181 runs in just 24 overs which then took the Indian lead to 364 runs. With this target, the West Indian batters lost two wickets on the final session of the fourth day. With 289 runs to win on the final day, the rain played the spoilsport and hence we end the match in a draw.

 

Mohammed Siraj is the Player of the Match
Mohammed Siraj: "This is my first Player of the Match award in Tests, so I am very happy. There wasn't much help for the Pacers, so performing here feels good. I kept my plans simple and executed. When you pick wickets in conditions like this, you get great confidence. The captain asked me to believe in myself and enjoy."


Kraigg Brathwaite, West Indies captain: "We showed some fight in this game with the bat. We can be more disciplined with the ball. It was a good comeback from the batters. We lost five wickets yesterday, that wasn't good. We had 98 overs on a pitch that was relatively good and we were positive. Unfortunately with the weather, we didn't get a chance. Alick looked good. Kirk looked good in his first match. These two guys showed promise. I have a lot of belief in these two. Preparation is important. We need to bat for long periods against good teams."


Rohit Sharma, India captain: "Every win is different. Playing here has its own challenge. We gave it a good shot, unfortunately, we couldn't get any play today. We were quite confident. We always wanted that kind of score where we wanted to challenge the opposition. There wasn't much on the surface. Siraj, I have been watching closely. He's taken such a giant step. He has led this attack. I don't want anyone to lead the attack. You want the entire pace attack to take responsibility. You need guys like Ishan. We wanted quick runs, we promoted him, he wasn't afraid. In Test matches, you need guys who stabilize the innings like Virat did, he played superbly. You need a mixture of everything. We have depth, and we have got variety. We are in the right place."
