IND - 55/4 (11 rpo, 5x4, 3x6)   II  AFG - 32/5 (6.4 rpo, 2x4, 2x6)

 

 

 

In an impressive performance,  India triumphs over Afghanistan by 47 runs in their first Super 8 encounter. India, batting first, set a formidable total of 181 runs for 8 wickets in 20 overs. Suryakumar Yadav led the charge with a blistering 53 off 28 balls, supported by Hardik Pandya's 32 and Rishabh Pant's quickfire 20. Afghanistan's bowlers, particularly Fazalhaq Farooqi and Rashid Khan, who both took three wickets each, tried to contain the Indian batsmen but could not prevent a high total. 

Chasing 182, Afghanistan struggled to build momentum against a disciplined Indian bowling attack. Jasprit Bumrah was exceptional, taking 3 wickets for just 7 runs in his 4 overs, while Arshdeep Singh also claimed 3 wickets. Despite a valiant effort by Azmatullah Omarzai, who scored 26 off 20 balls, Afghanistan was bowled out for 134 in 20 overs. India's comprehensive victory by 47 runs showcased their batting depth and bowling prowess, securing them a well-deserved win. 

 

 

 

SKY is Player of the Match 

Suryakumar Yadav: "A lot of hard work and practice has gone behind this performance. There's a lot of routine and process involved, and I’m very clear about what to do when I go out to bat. I don't mind sharing this Player of the Match award with a bowler as well. This is the first for a batter, and I hope it's the first of many. Facing Rashid Khan is always tough; he's challenging to get away. Adjusting from the US to the West Indies, it's crucial to have a clear game plan. Putting the team first is essential when you step out there. I remember telling Hardik not to leave too much for the end when the ball gets old and starts reversing. Our plan was to push the pedal and see where we stood at 16 overs, then take it from there."

 

 

Rashid Khan, Afghanistan Skipper: "We knew we'd be chasing around 160-170 given it was against a stronger team. We could have achieved it if we had executed our plans more smartly. My bowling has been improving; I struggled early in the IPL, but now I'm consistently hitting the right areas. However, the match result is what matters most. We've enjoyed playing cricket everywhere, but our mindset is crucial. If the conditions are favourable, we'll adapt our strategy based on whether it's a batting or bowling track."
 

 

Rohit Sharma, India Skipper:  "The last two years, we've played T20s here, so we understand the conditions and planned accordingly. We adapted well and scored 180, which was a great effort from the batters. Our bowlers were exceptional, defending the total perfectly. Everyone came in and did their job, which is critical and something we focus on. The partnership between Suryakumar Yadav and Hardik Pandya was crucial at that point; we needed someone to bat deep, and they did just that. We all know Bumrah's class and what he can do. It's important for us to use him smartly regardless of conditions. He's always willing to take responsibility and has been doing it for years. Regarding the three-spinner combination, we have to assess the conditions and the opposition, and based on that, we're open to making changes if required. We felt that three spinners were the right choice here, but if the conditions are more seamer-friendly next time, we'll go with more seamers."

TossDetails: Bangladesh Won The Toss And Elected To Field
TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Field
CompetitionName: Icc Mens T20 World Cup 2024
PreMatchCommentary:
As the T20 World Cup Super 8 heats up, we turn our attention to a clash brimming with subcontinental flair: India vs Bangladesh.India, buoyed by a string of commanding performances, enters the fray with a lineup that’s the envy of the cricketing world. The spotlight shines on Suryakumar Yadav, whose willow has been scripting symphonies of destruction.Yet, the subplot of this cricketing drama revolves around Virat Kohli. The maestro, whose bat has gone quiet, faces the ultimate test of form and fortitude. Across the pitch, Bangladesh emerges, undeterred by past tribulations. Their bowling, spearheaded by the cunning Mustafizur Rahman, is a blend of experience and youthful exuberance, ready to exploit a surface that whispers promises of spin and bounce.The stage is set at Antigua, where the wicket, a spinner’s ally, awaits to play its part in this high-octane narrative. While India’s prowess is undeniable, Bangladesh’s tenacity in crunch situations is a testament to their spirit – a spirit that has often turned the tide against the mightiest.

Key players stand at the crossroads: Will Kohli’s blade sing once more? Can Dube rise to the occasion? For Bangladesh, the onus lies on their top order to lay a foundation robust enough to withstand India’s bowling onslaught.

This Super 8 encounter is not just a game; it’s a chapter in the annals of cricketing history. For India, it’s a step towards the semis; for Bangladesh, it’s a fight for survival. The stakes couldn’t be higher, and as the world watches, one thing is certain – this match will be a testament to the enduring allure of the gentleman’s game.


Head to Head :

 

TOSS : Bangladesh Won the Toss and Elected to Field 
 

Najmul Hossain Shanto | Bangladesh Skipper :"I would like to bowl first and try to restrict them to a low total so we can chase it down.It's a good opportunity for us to play here. We've played good cricket so far and we know the conditions well. Hopefully, we will put up a good show today.The wicket looks very good. I feel that 150-160 will be a good total to chase here.We have made one change: Taskin is out and Jaker Ali comes in." 

 

Rohit Sharma | India Skipper: "We wanted to bat first, and that's what we've got now. We need to put good runs on the board.The pitch looks good—nice and hard. It depends on how much the sun is beating down and making the pitch slow.We're playing the same team.This is an important game for us. We need to assess the conditions early. It's crucial to stay in the present and not worry about things that are out of our control."
PostMatchCommentary:

In a decisive T20 World Cup clash, India’s cricket team showcased their dominance with a 50-run triumph over Bangladesh, edging closer to the coveted semi-finals. The Men in Blue’s performance was nothing short of spectacular, with every player contributing to a victory that reverberated with skill and strategy.

The opening duo of Rohit Sharma and Virat Kohli laid a robust foundation, quickly amassing 39 runs. Despite their departures, the momentum didn’t falter. Rishabh Pant and Shivam Dube kept the scoreboard ticking, but it was Hardik Pandya who stole the show. His blistering 27-ball half-century was a masterclass in aggressive batting, leaving the Bangladesh bowlers scrambling for answers.

Bangladesh’s innings never quite took off, thanks to India’s bowling prowess. Kuldeep Yadav spun a web around the middle order, claiming three vital wickets. The pace duo of Jasprit Bumrah and Arshdeep Singh further tightened the noose, combining for four wickets and stifling Bangladesh’s chase.

Key moments like Pandya’s early wicket and Yadav’s spin magic were instrumental in dismantling Bangladesh’s batting line-up. The inability of the Bangladeshi batters to forge significant partnerships or adapt to the pitch conditions sealed their fate.

India’s emphatic victory not only bolstered their net run rate but also solidified their position at the top of Group 1. With a blend of disciplined bowling, resilient batting, and sharp fielding, India continues to assert their supremacy in the T20 format, inching ever closer to the semi-finals with a display of cricket that was both commanding and cohesive.

Player of the Match: Hardik Pandya  
 

Hardik Pandya: We have played good cricket and, more importantly, we have stuck together, with everyone stepping up at the right time in different situations.I didn't realize that the batters wanted to use the breeze. I just tried to bowl wide, which is my delivery. But the batter had already decided to hit there, so it was about staying one step ahead.As a group, we can get better. We are losing wickets in bunches during the middle stage, and we can improve that. But apart from that, we are looking good.For me, this World Cup is very special. I'm very fortunate to play for my country. It was a freak injury. I tried to come back, but god had other plans, and I couldn't make it. I always believe, and I was speaking to Rahul sir the other day. We said that luck comes to people who work hard. That's what I have been doing for the past few months, and I'm happy to be here."

 
 

Najmul Hossain Shanto | Bangladesh Skipper:"We were looking to restrict India to around 160 or 170. That would have been good for us. But credit to them for the way they played.It wasn't too hot when we batted. All the players are well-versed in these conditions.I think we had a lot of batting options today, but we didn't show the intent we needed. Chasing 190-odd, you need to go hard in the powerplay.I tried to bat well in every game and contribute, but I had to finish the game, which I didn't. I should have finished the game. Tanzim Hasan Sakib has done a great job in this tournament. I should also mention Rishad Hossain. We have been looking for a leg-spinner for a while, and it's good to have him." 

 

Rohit Sharma | India Skipper:"I have been talking about that for a long time. It's just about going out there and putting in the work. We know how to go out there and work. We did well to adapt to the conditions. Wind is a factor here, and you have to adapt to it. We were smart with the bat and adjusted well with the conditions here with the ball.All the batters need to play their roles, whatever they are. We saw only one batter get to 50 and still get to 190. It's not about getting to 50s or 100s. It's about going out there and playing their roles. Obviously, we have to adapt to the conditions, but we have a lot of experience in the side, and we want to back them to play their roles.Hardik's form puts us in a good position. Hardik being Hardik. We know what he is capable of, and he showed what he can do with the bat. He's a very important player for us. If he can do that, we will be in very good positions. You talk a lot off the field, but executing it on the field is different. We asked the bowlers to do some things on the field, and they delivered."

GroundName: Daren Sammy National Cricket Stadium, Gros Islet
TossDetails: Australia Won The Toss And Elected To Field
TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Field
CompetitionName: Icc Mens T20 World Cup 2024
PreMatchCommentary:
The Daren Sammy National Cricket Stadium in St. Lucia braces for a high-stakes T20 World Cup Super 8s clash. India, the undefeated juggernaut, takes on a slightly battered Australia, desperate to avoid an early knockout.

India's batting has been a fortress, with experienced campaigners Kohli and Rohit Sharma laying the groundwork. While they haven't unleashed their full potential yet, the middle order, led by the explosive Hardik Pandya, is a ticking time bomb. Their bowling attack boasts the wily Kuldeep Yadav and the fiery pace duo of Bumrah and Arshdeep Singh, a formidable unit ready to dismantle any batting lineup.

Australia, on the other hand, is in unfamiliar territory. Strategic blunders and individual woes have left them scrambling. Their shocking loss to Afghanistan still hangs heavy, and they face a must-win situation against India.Warner and Maxwell need to stand tall against India's bowling might. While their pace attack with Cummins and Starc can challenge any batsman, Australia needs more than just firepower to overcome India's juggernaut. 

As the cricketing cosmos gears up for this colossal clash, St. Lucia becomes the gladiatorial arena where heroes will emerge or falter. This isn’t just a tussle of bat and ball; it’s a tale of grit, strategy, and the unyielding spirit of the game.Who will rise to the occasion? The next chapter in this storied rivalry is about to be written, and it promises to be a thriller for the ages.

Head-To-Head in T20 World Cup:

In the five matches contested between the two, India Slightly edge over Aussies with three to two wins. In overall T20Is, India has dominated Australia with 19 wins to 11 losses.



Did You Know?

The last time Australia knocked India out of the World cup was in 2012 while the last time India knocked out Australia was in 2016, both of this occasions West Indies went on to win the T20 World Cup. They defeated Australia in 2012 semi finals while defeated India in 2016 semi finals.

India, Australia and Their T20 World Cup Nostalgia:

The first encounter between India and Australia in the T20 World Cup came in the semi-finals of the 2007 tournament. Yuvraj Singh's explosive innings of 70 runs off just 30 balls, including five fours and six sixes, helped India post a formidable total of 188/5. Sreesanth's fearsome bowling spell of 2/12 in his four overs then helped India outplay Australia by 15 runs, eventually leading them to win the inaugural T20 World Cup.


Another memorable encounter came in the Super 8 stage of the 2012 T20 World Cup, where Shane Watson single-handedly decimated the Indians with his all-round brilliance. He took three wickets to restrict India to 140/7 and then went berserk with the bat, scoring 72 runs off 42 balls to help Australia chase the target in just 15 overs.


The next special encounter was a virtual quarter-final between the two teams in the 2016 T20 World Cup. In this winner-take-all contest, Virat Kohli's masterclass performance stood out. Coming to bat when the stakes were high, Kohli scored an unbeaten 82 off 51 balls on a tough pitch, knocking Australia out of the contest. His innings is remembered as one of the best in the history of T20 World Cups.

 

Decoding The Bumrah's Masterclass:

Jasprit Bumrah has been brilliant with the ball, picking up 10 wickets in as many as five games at an impressive average of 6.50 and a phenomenal economy rate of 3.42. His economy rate is the best for a bowler in a World Cup season with a minimum of 100 balls bowled. His bowling has been key to the Indian team’s success in this tournament.


 

TOSS: Australia Won the Toss and Elected to Field
 

Mitchell Marsh | Australia Skipper:"We will bowl first. It's a belter. It's a quarter-final, and we are looking forward to it. It's a big challenge against India. We have found ourselves in this situation many times in this World Cup with our backs against the wall, but we understand the pressure situation.We have a great experienced group and have enjoyed the Caribbean. Today is a must-win, and the boys are up for it. Just one change: Starc comes in for Ashton Agar."



Rohit Sharma | India Skipper:"We would have fielded first as well. It looks a little sticky at this point, but we wanted to chase, having fielded first in a couple of games.The pitch looks good. Hopefully, it doesn't change too much. The overcast conditions also matter when you play in this part of the world. But we have adapted really well, and it's the same today.Every game matters in this tournament. For us, nothing changes. We will be playing with the same approach.We are playing with the same team."
PostMatchCommentary:

IND - 60/1 (10 rpo, 5x4, 5x6) || AUS - 65/1 (10.83 rpo, 7x4, 4x6)

Middle Overs (Overs 7- 15) :-
IND - 102/3 (11.3 rpo, 8x4, 7x6) || AUS - 76/3 (8.4 rpo, 8x4, 3x6)

Death Overs (Overs 16- 20) :-
IND - 43/1 (8.6 rpo, 1x4, 3x6) || AUS - 40/3 (8 rpo, 1x4, 2x6) 
 

India has once again roared like a lion on the cricket field, clinching a spot in the semifinals with a commanding 24-run triumph over the Aussies. It was a spectacle at St. Lucia, where despite a hiccup after the coin toss, the Men in Blue batted with a ferocity that set the stage ablaze. The captain, Rohit Sharma, was the maestro of the innings, hammering a whirlwind 92 off just 41 deliveries, steering India to a daunting 205/5.

The Aussies, in response, showed a spark with Marsh and Head stitching together a partnership that had promise. But then came the twist in the tale – India’s bowlers, with Kuldeep leading the charge, turned the tide. A boundary catch that’ll be etched in memories for ages by Axar, and crucial wickets including the big fish, Maxwell, swung the momentum India’s way.

Arshdeep’s lethal spell sent the middle order packing, and Bumrah’s precision choked the Aussie chase. With a mountain to climb in the last over, Pandya’s guile ensured Australia fell short, mustering only four runs.

Now, Australia’s fate hangs by a slender thread, while India strides with swagger into the semis, setting up a titanic clash with England. This isn’t just a win; it’s a statement – India’s unwavering spirit and prowess have shone through, proving their mettle on the world stage.

 

Mitchell Marsh | Australia Skipper:"It's disappointing. We still have a chance technically of making it to the semi-finals, but India outplayed us today.India are a better team. Rohit Sharma is a world-class player, and we've seen that for the past 15 years. He took the game away from us at the start.There's more belief in the dressing room. In a run chase like that, you have to keep yourselves in the game and take it deep. But India were strong in the end with the ball." 

Player of the Match: Rohit Sharma

Rohit Sharma | India Captain:"It's quite satisfying, especially when you are playing like that. We know Australia quite well. Overall, as a team, we played well and kept doing the things that we are supposed to do.200 is a good score, but when you're playing on a ground like this where wind is a big factor, anything is possible. We used the conditions well. You need to understand what needs to be done as individuals. Whoever steps up needs to do their job. It is pleasing to see how we were going through the overs and taking wickets as well.We understand the strength Kuldeep has. The New York wickets were seamer-friendly, and unfortunately, he had to miss out. He has come here and done the job for us in the last two games. That's what I am looking for from the team: everyone playing their role perfectly."

TossDetails: England Won The Toss And Elected To Field
TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Field
CompetitionName: Icc Mens T20 World Cup 2024
PreMatchCommentary:
The two most consistent teams in the white-ball circuit, India and England, are set to battle it out in the second semi-final of the ICC T20 World Cup 2024 on June 27th at the Providence Stadium in Guyana. This will be the fifth pair of teams to play multiple T20 World Cup semi-finals against each other.

India enters the contest riding high on confidence after impressive performances in the tournament, comfortably winning all their fixtures. They have shown resistance, grit, and determination throughout the tournament, with vital contributions from all team members in different in-game situations. Rohit Sharma showcased his class, leading from the front against Australia with a scintillating 41-ball 92, including 15 boundaries. If Rohit was the protagonist in that victory, Kuldeep Yadav backed his captain up with an excellent spell of 2/24 in a high-scoring affair. Jasprit Bumrah's performances in the tournament have been world class, with a flurry of wicket-taking deliveries while showcasing his ability to control runs. This dominant Indian side will look to continue their winning run with a mix of caution and aggression.

England, the defending champions, enter the fray rejuvenated by their journey so far in the Super Eight. From being on the brink of elimination after a washout and a loss to Australia to facing India in the semi-finals, their journey has been remarkable. England are not only the Defending Champions but also the Champions of the last T20 World Cup held in the Caribbean. Adil Rashid and Jofra Archer have been their standout bowlers picking up 9 wickets each, while Chris Jordan was impressive in the last game, securing a hat-trick: the first England bowler to achieve this feat in this format. The English batting unit has been bolstered by Jos Butler and Phil Salt, with both doing the bulk of the scoring with 191 and 183 runs, respectively.

The stakes are high for this big clash. Will it be Dejavu for England in the semifinal with the goal of retaining their status as T20 World Champions or Will India avenge their 2022 loss and reach their second consecutive ICC event final? Who will come out on top in this epic clash?

Head-To-Head in T20Is:
When it comes to head-to-head battles, India and England have always been fierce competitors. Out of 23 games contested between the two teams, India holds a slight edge with 12 wins to England's 11. In T20 World Cup history, both teams have faced each other four times, each winning two games.


 

India, England and their Consistent Run:

India and England have been consistent performers in recent times, qualifying for the knock-outs in five of the last six ICC white-ball tournaments. Both teams aim to finish the tournament on a high note and have the capability to do so.



A Tale of Two Similar Leaders:

India win this contest in a commanding manner! England elected to field first after winning the toss, aiming to capitalize on overcast conditions that hinted at favourable bowling weather. However, the decision didn't pan out as expected. India, despite losing Virat Kohli early for a modest nine runs, found their hero in Rohit Sharma, who anchored the innings with a pivotal half-century. Suryakumar Yadav contributed a brisk 47 from 36 balls, while Hardik Pandya and Ravindra Jadeja added quickfire scores of 23 and 17*, respectively, pushing India to a fighting total of 171/7. England's response was aggressive from the outset, with Jos Buttler charging the Indian pacers, but the momentum shifted when Axar Patel dismissed him for 23. The introduction of Jasprit Bumrah and Kuldeep Yadav further tightened India's grip on the match. Axar was particularly effective, claiming crucial wickets, while Kuldeep snagged three wickets, ending with impressive figures of 3/19. Harry Brook tried to rally with 25 runs, but a costly mix-up with Jofra Archer cut short Liam Livingstone's promising innings. Despite Archer's late hitting, the English side couldn't overcome the disciplined Indian bowling, and the match concluded with India securing a solid victory. And this victory makes it to their 3rd final of ICC T20 World Cup. The Men in Blue  will now face South Africa in the grand finale in Barbados on Saturday (June 29). It is fitting that the two undefeated sides will meet in the final of a World Cup.

 

AXAR PATEL (MAN OF THE MATCH) :  "I've often taken on the role of bowling during the powerplay, and that was our strategy going into the game. Recognizing the assistance the pitch provided for spin and its tendency to halt the ball, I aimed for simplicity in my execution. The pitch was slow, and it was clear that it would be challenging for the batters to score freely. Based on that, I adjusted my pace to be a bit slower today, and fortunately, it paid off. Our batsmen had pointed out the difficulty in hitting on this wicket, noting that some deliveries were staying low and skidding. Given this, we were confident that setting a target above 150 would be competitive. The partnership between Rohit and Suryakumar was crucial. They managed to hit the boundary when needed and kept the scoreboard ticking with smart rotations of the strike. As for this Player of the Match award, I'm focusing on celebrating this achievement in the knockout stages first, without getting ahead of myself about the final in Barbados."

 

ROHIT SHARMA (INDIA CAPTAIN): "It's incredibly satisfying to come away with a win today. The team has put in a lot of hard work, and I'm proud of how everyone stepped up. We adjusted superbly to the conditions, which were far from easy, and that adaptability has been crucial to our success so far. Originally, we thought 140-150 runs might be enough, but during the middle overs, SKY and I picked up the pace, aiming for an extra 20-25 runs. I wanted to ensure our batsmen could play freely, based on their instincts. Eventually, setting a target of 175 turned out to be excellent given the circumstances. Our bowlers were outstanding. Axar and Kuldeep, our lead spinners, made it very challenging for the batsmen in these conditions, to maintain their composure under pressure. After the first innings, we focused on keeping the stumps in play, and they executed this perfectly. Regarding Virat Kohli, his class is undeniable. With his extensive experience, form is never a concern, and he might just be saving his best for the final. As a team, we've maintained our composure, which is essential for making sound decisions during crucial moments like today. The final is a significant occasion, but staying composed will be key to our success. We haven't won an ICC trophy since 2013, but we are in good form and hopeful about putting on a strong performance in the finals."

 

JOS BUTTLER(ENGLAND CAPTAIN):  "Today, India was simply the better team. We allowed them a few too many runs towards the end, which set us back on a challenging pitch. It's a different scenario from two years ago, and full credit to India—they fully deserved this victory. Regarding the toss decision, considering the weather conditions, I didn't anticipate much change in the playing conditions, which proved true. However, India's bowling was superior. In hindsight, perhaps we should have utilized Moeen Ali more, given how effective spin proved to be. Though we ended up chasing a target that was quite tough, I'm proud of the effort everyone put in throughout this competition. We've faced significant challenges and shown some excellent cricket at times."

CompetitionName: Icc Mens T20 World Cup 2024
PreMatchCommentary:
The grand finale of the ICC T20 World Cup 2024 is set to take place in Barbados on June 29th, where the two dominant teams, South Africa and India, will clash for the one last time. Both teams remain undefeated in the tournament, with South Africa winning eight games and India winning seven.


India enters the contest on the back of a stellar tournament performance. They have been clinical in every match, with each player rising to the occasion when needed. Led by Rohit Sharma, who has delivered back-to-back fearless half-centuries against top teams, India has shown exceptional form. Their bowling attack, featuring Bumrah and Kuldeep, has been crucial in dismantling the opposition. India will be playing in their third T20 World Cup final and will be aiming to secure their second title.


South Africa, on the other hand, comes into the final brimming with confidence. They have made history by reaching the World Cup final for the first time, achieving eight consecutive victories. Despite facing pressure at various points, different players have consistently stepped up to secure wins. Markram’s brilliant captaincy, combined with de Kock’s outstanding batting and the finishing prowess of Miller and Klaasen, supported by a formidable bowling attack, has brought them to this point. They are determined to cap off their campaign with their first-ever World Cup title.


The stakes are incredibly high for this finale, as it marks the first time both finalists have remained undefeated throughout the tournament. Which team will emerge victorious and lift the coveted trophy? The anticipation is at its peak as cricket fans worldwide await this epic showdown.

Head- To-Head in T20 World Cup:
In as many as six games played between the two teams, India has won four games while South Africa has emerged victorious twice. Overall in T20Is India has won 14 games while losing 11.



The Captain Magnificent In The ICC Events:

Both Rohit Sharma and Aiden Markram has been excellent when comes to captaincy, Markram has captained 10 matches for South Africa in ICC events and has won all the games, he has also led SA to under 19 title win in 2014, while Rohit in his 24 outings has won 21 games. Interestingly one of his three losses came against South Africa in T20 World Cup and other two losses came in semi final of T20 World Cup and final of ODI World Cup.



India, South Africa and their ICC Knock Out Meetings:

In the three games played between the two teams, India have emerged victorious on all three occasions while South Africa are yet to win a knock out game against India.



Interesting Numbers and Stats From T20 World Cup Finals:

 In the T20 World Cup finals so far, teams chasing has won six times out off eight games while teams batting first has defended only twice. India is one among the two teams to win the game while defending in the finals along with West Indies. Interestingly India have batted first in both of their finals, winning one and losing one.

 

PITCH REPORT:

Nasser Hussain: "We're at one of the premier cricket venues in the world, the Kensington Oval in Barbados, for the final between South Africa and India. The temperature is forecasted to be around 30 degrees Celsius, with a 30% chance of rain, which we hope reduces to zero. There is a 30 kmph wind blowing towards the shorter side. In terms of dimensions, the square boundaries are 63m and 65m, the straight hit is 73m, and the pockets are 71m and 69m."

 

Ian Bishop: "This surface is quite interesting. There's been a lot of rolling, but no live grass to hold it together. I think it’s initially quite hard. I’m hoping the ball will come onto the bat nicely. Notably, more wickets have fallen to the pacers here."

 

TOSS:

ROHIT CALLS IT RIGHT, INDIA WON THE TOSS AND ELECTED TO BAT FIRST! 

 

Rohit Sharma (India Captain): "We’ve decided to bat first. The pitch looks good. We’ve already played a game here, and the totals have been solid. It’s all about understanding our roles and staying composed. We’re up against a strong team, but we need to remain calm and take responsibility as we’ve done so far. Both South Africa and we have been playing good cricket. It’s going to be a competitive match between two quality sides. Various players have stepped up for us in different situations, and we’re hoping for the same today. Same Lineup for us"

 

Aiden Markram (South Africa Captain): "Yes, we wanted to bat first too. The pitch looks dry, but now we get the first chance with the ball to put them under pressure early. We haven’t always been at our best, but we’ve still won games. We’ll draw confidence from that. Perfection isn’t possible, but we aim to get as close as we can. This is a fantastic opportunity with no pressure on us. We’ve never been here before, but you can’t win the trophy without reaching the final. Same team for us"

The wait is over—India are the world Champions  after a decade, showcasing resilience and precision under pressure. The scene at Kensington Oval is electric, with the Indian squad overwhelmed with joyous tears. Rohit Sharma has steered his team out of a decade-long trophy drought, leading an unbeaten campaign. The spotlight also shines brightly on Hardik Pandya. This victory brings an ICC trophy back to Indian shores. The crowd stands in ovation, recognizing the intense battle on the field. Virat Kohli's crucial innings and Jasprit Bumrah's game-changing spells were pivotal, while Arshdeep Singh's composed 19th over finally redeemed his past oversights. A glorious day for Indian cricket champions once more! 1.3 Billion Hearts are happy 

 

India opted to bat first and posted a respectable total of 176, thanks to Virat Kohli's crucial fifty—the first of his tournament. Kohli steadied the innings following early dismissals of Rohit and Rishabh, crafting a masterful knock that proved vital in the match's outcome. Contributions from Shivam Dube and Axar Patel also bolstered the Indian score. In response, South Africa faltered early with Hendricks and Markram succumbing to Bumrah and Arshdeep's swing and pace respectively. Stubbs countered effectively, propelling the Proteas post-powerplay, though his effort was short-lived. The real momentum shift came through de Kock and Klaasen; Klaasen was particularly aggressive, smashing a rapid 23-ball fifty. With the game seemingly tilting in South Africa's favor, needing 30 runs from the final five overs, India's bowlers staged a remarkable comeback. Hardik Pandya dismissed Klaasen, Bumrah claimed Jansen, and Arshdeep Singh bowled an economical penultimate over. Hardik then sealed the deal, defending the totals skillfully in the final over to clinch a 7-run victory for India.

India has joined the elite ranks of West Indies (2012 and 2016) and England (2010 and 2022) by securing their second T20 World Cup title in 2024, having first triumphed in 2007. Remarkably, this victory marks only the third instance in T20 World Cup history where a team has successfully defended a total in the final. India's squad replicated their 2007 feat this year, a distinction they share with West Indies, who accomplished this in 2012.

 

Virat Kohli, Player of the Match: "This was my final T20 World Cup, and it was about now or never. Stepping up when it truly counted in my last T20I for India, that’s what I wanted. I’m deeply grateful—God has been kind. Yes, it wasn’t a secret. I had made it clear this was my last T20I World Cup outing. This was my last T20 game playing for Indian team. We have many talented young players ready to take India forward. It's been a prolonged wait to secure another ICC title, not just for me but for Rohit too. He's competed in nine T20 World Cups and truly deserved this victory, as did the rest of our team. The resilience and character displayed by the team were phenomenal. Once the emotions settle, my overwhelming feeling will be gratitude for this incredible journey."

 

Jasprit Bumrah, Player of the Tournament: "I'm usually the one keeping my emotions in control, focusing on the task at hand, but today, I'm at a loss for words. I don't normally cry after a match, but the emotions are just overwhelming. We were in a tough spot, and to come back and win from there, with my family in the stands, is just indescribable. We came close last time, and now, having played my part in clinching this victory, there's no better feeling. Throughout the tournament, I kept myself focused, stayed in my bubble, not thinking too far ahead. When the big day came, I knew I just had to deliver. I focus on one ball, one over at a time, trying not to let emotions get the best of me. But now that it's over, it's time to let those emotions out, to scream and shout. When asked to bowl the crucial 16th over, noticing the ball was slightly scuffed, I knew it might reverse. I strategized on the toughest shots for the batter and executed my plans perfectly."

 

 

Aiden Markram (South Africa Captain): "Certainly, it's tough to swallow right now. We'll need some time to process this. Nonetheless, I'm immensely proud of the team's effort throughout the tournament. Our bowling performance was commendable given the tough pitch conditions. We managed to limit India to a chaseable score. Though it's disappointing not to clinch the win, I'm full of pride for our squad's resilience. Throughout this tournament, we've seen how quickly the dynamics of a game can shift. We never took our position for granted, aware that the outcome could swing at any moment. We believed we were in a prime position to take home the trophy, but fate had other plans. Looking forward, I'm optimistic. One thing's for sure: the South African team will always fight fiercely and stay competitive to the very end. Despite the setback, today remains a moment of pride for us all."

 

Rohit Sharma (India Captain): "It's difficult to encapsulate everything we've experienced over the past few years. We've dedicated immense effort both individually and as a team. The preparation and strategic planning aren't just about today but reflect a sustained effort over time. When the stakes were high, everyone understood their roles and performed under pressure. Even when momentum seemed to favour South Africa, we managed to stay composed. Winning a tournament involves a lot of behind-the-scenes effort. Throughout this tournament, our performance was exceptional. Regarding Virat Kohli, his consistent excellence over the last 15 years meant that we were confident he would deliver in crucial moments. Today, he anchored our innings brilliantly, allowing others to build around him. Axar's batting was pivotal in boosting our score to a competitive total. Jasprit Bumrah’s contribution is hard to summarize; his ability to consistently deliver under pressure is nothing short of remarkable. I’m immensely proud of this team. The support from our fans has been overwhelming, from those here in Barbados to the millions back home staying up late to support us. Their energy fuels our passion and commitment on the field."

Zimbabwe emerged victorious by 13 runs. Batting first, Zimbabwe scored 115 for 9 in their 20 overs. Madhevere contributed 21 runs from 22 balls, and Brian Bennett added 22 runs from 15 balls. Captain Raza scored 17 runs from 19 balls, while Dion Myers chipped in with 23 runs from 22 balls. Clive Madande was the top scorer with an unbeaten 29 runs from 25 balls. For India, Ravi Bishnoi was the standout bowler, claiming 4 wickets for 13 runs in his 4 overs. Washington Sundar also impressed with figures of 2 for 11 from his 4 overs.

In response, India was bowled out for 102 in 19.5 overs. Shubman Gill top-scored with 31 runs from 29 balls, and Washington Sundar made 27 runs from 34 balls. However, the rest of the batting lineup struggled, with only Avesh Khan (16 runs from 12 balls) and Ravi Bishnoi (9 runs from 8 balls) reaching notable scores. For Zimbabwe, Raza led the bowling attack with 3 wickets for 25 runs, while Chatara picked up 3 wickets for 16 runs, helping Zimbabwe secure a 13-run win.

 

Shubman Gill, Indian Skipper: "We bowled pretty well, but we let ourselves down in the field. Our performance wasn't up to standard, and everyone seemed a bit rusty. We had discussed taking our time and enjoying our batting, but it didn't turn out that way. By the halfway mark, we had lost 5 wickets. It would have been ideal if I had stayed till the end, so I am very disappointed with how I got out and how the rest of the match unfolded. There was a glimmer of hope for us, but when you're chasing 115 and your number 10 batter is out there, you know something has gone wrong."
 

 

Sikandar Raza is Player of the Match 
 

Sikandar Raza, Zimbabwe Skipper: "I feel really happy about the win. We need to take it one game at a time because the job is not done and the series is not over. World champions play like world champions, so we need to be ready for the next game. This isn't a wicket where you get bowled out for 115, so credit to the bowlers of both sides. It's clearly an indication that we need to up our skills. I said I don't care about the result as long as we stay true to the crowd and the changing room. We had our plans, we stuck to them, and we backed our guys. Our catching and ground fielding were amazing, but we did make some errors, which shows there's room for improvement. We knew the fans would lift us up and give us energy, and credit to them—it really helped us."

In the second T20 between India and Zimbabwe, India batted first and amassed 234 for 2 in their 20 overs. Shubman Gill, the captain, departed early, but that did not slow down Abhishek Sharma. Sharma played a brilliant innings, scoring 100 runs off 47 balls with 7 fours and 8 sixes before being caught by Myers off Masakadza. Ruturaj Gaikwad remained unbeaten with 77 runs off 47 balls, hitting 11 fours and 1 six, while Rinku Singh also stayed not out, smashing 48 runs off 22 balls with 2 fours and 5 sixes.

In response, Zimbabwe was all out for 134 in 18.4 overs. Wessly Madhevere was the top scorer with 43 runs off 39 balls. The Indian bowlers kept constant pressure on the hosts, maintaining control over their scoring rate. Mukesh Kumar and Avesh Khan were the most successful bowlers, each taking three wickets. Ravi Bishnoi claimed two wickets, while Washington Sundar took one. 

 

 

Sikandar Raza, Zimbabwe Skipper: "The world champions will ultimately perform like world champions. Dropping catches today impacted us. I anticipated a score of 200 on this pitch, but they ended up with 30 runs more. Before this game, I thought it would be a tight match, but it didn't turn out that way as our top-order struggled. He has shown tremendous growth, demonstrating a strong desire to succeed, and his performance will keep improving. This is something we've been addressing for a long time; today, we came in with a positive mindset and played our shots."
 

 

Abhishek Sharma is the Player of the Match 

Abhishek Sharma: "I think my performance today was quite good, especially considering the tough defeat we faced yesterday. I felt that today was my day, and I made it count. In T20 cricket, it's all about momentum, and I carried it through to the end. Special thanks to the coach and team management for their support. As a youngster, it's important to express yourself when you have the opportunity. We were discussing after every ball, and he encouraged me to take charge and go for it."

 

Shubman Gill, Indian Skipper: "I'm very happy to be back to winning ways. Abhishek and Rutu's batting was exceptional, especially considering the challenging powerplay with the ball moving around. Yesterday, our issue was more about handling the pressure, which was tough for our young team experiencing their first international exposure. We still have three matches to go. It's always better to have more options than to be limited in choices."

Ladies and gentlemen, we're poised for a cracker of a contest at Harare Sports Club! The five-match T20I series between India and Zimbabwe hangs in the balance at 1-1, setting the stage for a pivotal third encounter.After a shock upset in the opener, the Men in Blue roared back with a clinical 100-run demolition job. Now, with the series on a knife-edge, both sides are pulling out all the stops.

 

India's camp is buzzing with the return of their T20 World Cup heroes - the explosive Yashasvi Jaiswal, the dynamic Sanju Samson, and the hard-hitting Shivam Dube. Skipper Shubman Gill finds himself in the enviable position of having to juggle a star-studded lineup. Meanwhile, Zimbabwe's talismanic leader Sikandar Raza is rallying his troops, determined to recapture their early series magic.

The Indian think tank faces some delicious dilemmas. Will we see Jaiswal unleashed at the top, reshuffling the batting order? Samson's likely to don the gloves, adding his wealth of experience behind the stumps. And let's not forget Dube - a genuine game-changer with both bat and ball.

Zimbabwe, however, are grappling with consistency woes. The promising duo of Wessly Madhevere and Brian Bennett have shown glimpses of brilliance, but the hosts desperately need a collective effort to topple the Indian juggernaut. Their bowling unit, after being taken to the cleaners last time out, must channel the spirit of their opening match heroics.

Abhishek's scintillating century was the highlight, while Gaikwad's composed fifty provided the perfect foil.

As we look ahead to this crucial fixture, India's reinforcements add an extra layer of intrigue. Will they stick with the winning combination or unleash their returning stars?

Who will seize the momentum in this seesaw battle? Will it be India's firepower or Zimbabwe's home advantage that proves decisive? The anticipation is palpable as we count down to what promises to be a humdinger at Harare Sports Club. Buckle up - we're in for a treat!

What a thrilling match! India, led by the dynamic Shubman Gill, secured a 23-run victory over Zimbabwe in the third match, taking a 2-1 lead in the series. Opting to bat first, India posted 182/4, thanks to Gill's stellar 66 off 49 balls and Ruturaj Gaikwad's explosive 49 off 28 balls. Yashasvi Jaiswal contributed 36 off 27 balls, with late cameo from Sanju Samson. Zimbabwe's bowlers Blessing Muzarabani and Sikandar Raza took 2 wickets each but faced resistance from the Indian batsmen. Chasing 183, Zimbabwe's top order crumbled to 39/5, but Dion Myers' unbeaten 65 off 49 balls showed resilience. Clive Madande and Wellington Masakadza added support, but it was insufficient as they ended at 159/6. Washington Sundar starred with the ball, claiming 3 wickets for 15 runs, supported by Avesh Khan's 2 wickets and Khaleel Ahmed's economical spell. Key moments included Gill and Gaikwad's 72-run partnership and Sundar's crucial breakthroughs. India's comprehensive performance leaves Zimbabwe needing a strong comeback in the next match. Stay tuned as the series heats up! 

 

Sikandar Raza| Zimbabwe Captain:"Yeah, I think it's our fielding again. We pride ourselves on our fielding, but the wheels have come off in the last few games. If we had fielded well, we would have been in the game. We also have issues at the top of the order that need fixing.Unfortunately, we've tried 15 different opening pairs, but nothing has clicked. It's time for the players, myself included, to step up and take responsibility. I can understand mistakes from youngsters, but some of us have played over 40 T20Is, and we need to shoulder the responsibility.I'm an option for the top order, but we also need some experience in the middle order. This is the best team we have, and we need to back them" 

Player of the Match - Washington Sundar

Washington Sundar :"Feels amazing. To perform for the country is always special. Yes, it feels amazing. It was definitely a better wicket today. In the first two matches, there was something in it for the bowlers. Today, it was much better for batting. Zimbabwe did put a bit of pressure on us. That partnership between Myers and Madande put some pressure on us, but we are happy to go over the line. We have plenty of places to visit here in Zimbabwe. Hopefully, we finish the series on Saturday." 



Shubman Gill | India Captain:"Feels good going 2-1 up in the series. It was a crucial game for us. Yeah, definitely, it looked like we would go over 200. It was not easy to hit the length ball, and that's what Ruturaj and I were discussing in the middle. That was the message we gave to our bowlers, and they executed it perfectly.Everyone is contributing, from the openers to the bowlers. It makes the job easier."

TossDetails: India Won The Toss And Elected To Field

CompetitionName: India Tour Of Zimbabwe T20I Series 2024
PreMatchCommentary:
In the penultimate clash of the T20I series at Harare Sports Club, India looks to seal the series, leading 2-1 against Zimbabwe. After an unexpected hiccup in the opener, India bounced back with two emphatic victories, flexing their cricketing muscle and depth. The return of Yashasvi Jaiswal, Sanju Samson, and Shivam Dube from the T20 World Cup squad has added firepower to the team. Skipper Shubman Gill has been a rock at the top, and the middle order has fired on all cylinders, making India a formidable opponent. In the last game, India posted a competitive 182/4, thanks to solid contributions from Gill, Jaiswal, and a brisk cameo by Samson. Despite being a bit of a circus in the field, Zimbabwe managed to recover from a dismal 39/5 to 159/6, with Dion Myers and Clive Madande putting on a brave 77-run stand. However, their performance still fell short, with glaring fielding and batting inconsistencies. As we gear up for the fourth T20I, Zimbabwe faces a must-win scenario. They must sharpen their fielding and deliver a cohesive performance to stay in the hunt. India, brimming with confidence, aims to wrap up the series. With a pitch likely to favour spinners, expect some fireworks. Will Zimbabwe level the series and keep the dream alive, or will India crush their hopes? Buckle up, fans, for an epic showdown!

Head to Head :


PITCH REPORT:

Tino Mawoyo and Abhinav Mukund: "Today's game will be played on a fresh pitch. During our inspection, we noticed that the groundsmen had watered it yesterday, which means there might be some early moisture to assist the pacers. The pitch retains a bit more grass than usual. One boundary is quite short, measuring in the 60s, while the opposite side is longer, around the 80s. Indian pacers, known for their skiddy nature, have been effective at hitting the good length. Conversely, Zimbabwe's taller bowlers can exploit fuller lengths and generate bounce. Spinners will also find some assistance. Although Zimbabwe has started to read Bishnoi and Sundar better as the series has progressed, there’s still a lot of work ahead. This looks like the best pitch of the series so far."


TOSS: INDIA WON THE TOSS AND ELECTED TO FIELD!

 

Shubman Gill (India Captain): "We've decided to bowl first. The pitch seems fresh and from what the groundsmen mentioned, it’s been watered and should offer something for the fast bowlers. There are areas we need to improve, particularly in controlling the runs during the death overs. We got a bit complacent last time, so we'll be focusing on tightening up in that aspect. Tushar makes his debut."

 

Sikandar Raza (Zimbabwe Captain): "Our plan was to bat first today. Although the pitch is fresh, it tends to slow down later on in this region, so batting first seemed ideal. We're building towards our vision for 2026, and it's fantastic to have India here giving our players valuable game time. I'm hopeful our top three will make a strong start today. We need all three departments to perform well. If we can achieve that, we stand a good chance. After two tough games, I believe the team is eager and ready to bounce back."

The young Indian squad has proven too formidable for the Sikandar Raza-led Zimbabwe team, dominating the match comprehensively. Shubman Gill, continuing his winning streak at the toss, chose to bowl first on a fresh pitch. Tushar Deshpande, making his debut, and Khaleel Ahmed struggled initially with the new ball as Tadiwanashe Marumani and Wessly Madhevere forged a 63-run partnership for the first wicket. However, India's fifth and sixth bowlers, Abhishek Sharma and Shivam Dube, dismissed Marumani (32 off 31) and Madhevere (25 off 24) in consecutive overs, bringing India back into the contest. Zimbabwe lost momentum as wickets fell steadily. Nevertheless, skipper Sikandar Raza opted for an aggressive approach, scoring 46 off 28 balls, Once Raza was dismissed in the 19th over, India restricted Zimbabwe to 152/7 on a promising batting surface. Khaleel Ahmed rebounded effectively in the death overs, finishing with figures of 2/32. Tushar Deshpande claimed his first international wicket by dismissing the key player, Raza. Sundar, Abhishek, and Dube each took a wicket, while Bishnoi remained wicketless for the second game in a row. In response, Yashasvi Jaiswal and Shubman Gill launched a relentless assault on the Zimbabwean bowlers, forging an unbroken 156-run partnership. Jaiswal was the more aggressive, scoring 93 off 53 balls with 13 fours and 2 sixes. Gill, after a cautious start, found his rhythm and notched up his second consecutive fifty of the series, remaining unbeaten on 58 off 39 balls with 5 fours and 2 sixes. Zimbabwe's six bowlers were unable to break through and were thoroughly outplayed.

 

Sikandar Raza (Zimbabwe Captain): "I believe the pitch was a bit on the slower side at the start, perhaps slightly damp. We aimed for a total around 160, which we thought would be competitive, but credit where it's due – their batting was exceptional today. Even 180 might not have been sufficient. Today, we must acknowledge that they outplayed us with the bat. We aim to come back stronger in the final game of the series. We need to improve in all three areas of the game. Even if we end the series at 2-3, it would still be a respectable outcome."

 

Yashasvi Jaiswal (Player of the Match): "I thoroughly enjoyed today. The pitch was favourable, and I had specific plans for each bowler which made my batting experience enjoyable. When the ball was new, it came onto the bat nicely. But as it aged, it slowed down. I adjusted my approach accordingly. Shubman and I have great chemistry while batting together. Initially, I aimed to go hard in the first 10 overs, but after spending some time in the middle, I understood how to adapt and stay unbeaten till the end to secure the win for our team."

 

Shubman Gill (India Captain): "I’m thrilled with my first series win as captain, but the job isn’t finished yet. We still have one more game to play. Chasing was a key focus for us, and it's great to have accomplished that. This team is fantastic, a wonderful group of players. I hope we can continue to progress together. I haven’t had a discussion with the coach about any changes yet, but if there are any, I’ll update you at the toss."

TossDetails: Zimbabwe Won The Toss And Elected To Field

CompetitionName: India Tour Of Zimbabwe T20I Series 2024
PreMatchCommentary:
India is all set for a rapid turnaround as they gear up for the fifth and final T20I against Zimbabwe at the Harare Sports Club on Sunday, July 14. After a shocking loss in the series opener, the Shubman Gill-led Indian team has bounced back with a vengeance, winning the next three games to secure a 3-1 lead in the five-match series.

The latest victory was particularly emphatic, as India steamrolled Zimbabwe by 10 wickets, marking their dominance in the shortest format. Gill's impeccable record at the toss continued as he opted to bowl first in the fourth game. The Zimbabwean openers, Wessly Madhvere and Tadiwanashe Marumani, provided a sturdy start, but the middle order crumbled under pressure. Despite a valiant 46-run effort from Sikandar Raza, the hosts could only muster 152/7 in their 20 overs.

Tushar Deshpande, playing his debut series, redeemed himself with the crucial wicket of Raza after a shaky start. Khaleel Ahmed shone in the death overs, claiming two wickets, while Abhishek Sharma and Shivam Dube also chipped in with vital breakthroughs. Washington Sundar continued his consistent performance, and despite going wicketless, Ravi Bishnoi made an impact with his fielding prowess.

India's chase was a masterclass in batting. Yashasvi Jaiswal and Shubman Gill dismantled the Zimbabwean bowling attack with ease, guiding their team to victory in just 16 overs. Jaiswal's explosive 53-ball 93 and Gill's elegant 39-ball 58 ensured India reached the target without losing a wicket.

Looking ahead to the final game, India is expected to rotate their squad, possibly giving a chance to some new faces. The aim will be to finish the series on a high note with a 4-1 victory. Zimbabwe, on the other hand, will be playing for pride, hoping to salvage a win and end the series on a positive note.

Will India maintain their dominance, or can Zimbabwe pull off an upset in the final match?

Toss:- Zimbabwe have won the toss and opted to bowl first.

Sikandar Raza: "We're going to bowl first. The pitch tends to improve, so it should be better for batting in the second innings. We have the motivation, confidence, and skills needed. Chatara has been rested for this match".

Shubman Gill: "We were planning to bat first anyway. Our spinners have performed well, and the fast bowlers have been economical. The players are hungry and eager to play. It's challenging to play back-to-back matches. We have a couple of changes today - Mukesh Kumar and Parag are coming in."

India clinched the series 4-1 with a 42-run victory in the final T20I against Zimbabwe. put into bat first, India posted a competitive 167/6 in their allotted 20 overs. Sanju Samson stepped up when it mattered most, scoring a composed 58 off 45 balls. He was well-supported by Riyan Parag and Shivam Dube, who contributed 22 and 26 runs respectively, propelling India to a strong total.

In response, Zimbabwe struggled against India's bowling attack. Mukesh Kumar was the standout performer, claiming four crucial wickets. Despite an important 34-run knock from Myers and a late cameo from Faraz Akram, Zimbabwe fell short, managing only 125 runs before being bowled out. Shivam Dube also chipped in with two key wickets, ensuring India's dominance throughout the match.

This comprehensive win not only secured the series for India but also showcased the depth and resilience of their squad

Shivam Dube- Player of the Match: "Contributing in both batting and bowling is always special. Taking wickets felt great. T20s can be challenging, but one good shot can turn things around. The ground here is big, and we love playing in this amazing atmosphere with such fantastic people."

Washington Sundar- Player of the Series: "It's great to finish with a win. After the first game, we noticed conditions were similar to South Africa, with extra bounce and pace. We had plenty of time to gather insights. There are many takeaways and learnings from this series, and I got to bowl a lot. Our team had a lot of success together."

Sikandar Raza: "Blessing bowled excellently throughout the series. However, our batting fell short. What stands out for me is our fielding attitude, which we can improve. Richie wasn’t fit at the beginning, so having him fit now is fantastic. It's great to see Richie and Blessing working well together. I need to manage my workload, so I'll head back to play domestic cricket. I'm still available for Test matches, and I leave for the Hundred in a few days."


Shubman Gill: "It’s been an excellent series. The hunger and determination we showed after the first loss were phenomenal. Many of the players had long flights and were not used to the conditions, but their adaptation was remarkable. I've been to Sri Lanka once for the Asia Cup, and I'm looking forward to going there again and performing well".

PreMatchCommentary:
India and Sri Lanka are gearing up for a thrilling three-match T20I series starting on July 27, followed by three ODIs.


India, the visitors, enter the contest on the back of a 4-1 series victory over Zimbabwe. However, they will start this series with a new captain and coach, Surya Kumar Yadav and Gautam Gambhir, respectively. With veterans Kohli, Rohit, and Jadeja bidding farewell to the format, the onus now falls on Pant, Hardik, and Surya to lead the charge. These players have a knack for winning matches and will be eager to carry their form forward. Bumrah has been rested for the series to manage his workload.


Sri Lanka, on the other hand, come into the series after a disappointing T20 World Cup. They, too, have undergone changes in coaching and captaincy. Sanath Jayasuriya will serve as their interim coach, while the cool-headed Asalanka, who recently led Jaffna to a title triumph, is set to captain the team. Sri Lanka has added the experienced Chandimal and Perera to their squad for this series and will be looking to start on a positive note.


With both teams featuring new-look squads and the stakes sky-high, which team will emerge on top? Fans are eagerly anticipating a competitive and entertaining series.

Head-To-Head in T20Is:

In as many as 29 games battled between the two teams, India dominated the contest with 19 wins to Sri Lanka's 9 wins while one game ended in no result..


Pitch Report : 

"There's a cool breeze blowing across the ground, which will bring the temperature down. The surface is hard with some visible cracks.
Compared to the LPL surface, this one looks quite different, with more cracks. As the ball loses its hardness, it will tend to stick in the surface. However, it should still be good for batting, and we can expect plenty of runs here."


Toss:-
The Coin has Spun in the Lankan's Favour as they have decided to  first.

Charith Asalanka:- "We've decided to bowl first as the pitch looks promising, and we want to assess its behavior. We're opting for a 6-5 combination of batters and bowlers. Each player has a specific role, which is why we've chosen to go with 5 bowlers. You can look forward to more wins and consistent performances from our team."

Suryakumar Yadav:-"The pitch looks good, so we're fine with batting first. Our brand of cricket remains unchanged. The relationship between me and Gambhir has been special for many years. Dube, Samson, Khaleel, and Washington are the four players missing out today. The World Cup is behind us; we're starting fresh, and this is a new challenge."

India kicked off the series with a commanding 43-run victory over Sri Lanka, taking a 1-0 lead. Put into bat first, India set an imposing total of 213 for 7 in their 20 overs. The opening duo of Gill and Jaiswal got India off to a flying start, punishing the Sri Lankan bowlers with aggressive stroke play. The highlight of the innings was Surya Kumar Yadav's composed half-century, which stabilized the innings. Pant provided a late flourish, ensuring India reached a formidable score. Pathirana was the standout bowler for Sri Lanka, claiming four wickets.

In response, Sri Lanka began their chase with confidence as Pathum Nissanka and Kusal Mendis put together an 84-run opening stand. Mendis fell for a well-made 45, but Nissanka continued to anchor the innings, partnering with Perera to add another 50 runs. However, once Nissanka was dismissed, the Indian bowlers seized control. Sri Lanka's batting lineup crumbled, losing the last nine wickets for just 30 runs, ultimately falling short by 43 runs.

Riyan Parag was instrumental in India's bowling attack, picking up three wickets. Arshdeep Singh and Axar Patel also contributed significantly, each taking two wickets. India's balanced performance with both bat and ball highlighted their dominance, setting the tone for the rest of the series.

Player of the Match:
Suryakumar Yadav (India Skipper): "I believe they played a strong brand of cricket from the very first ball. Despite losing wickets, they maintained a high tempo. We had practiced here for two to three days and were well-prepared for the pitch conditions. Given that we recently won the World Cup, we never doubted our ability to stay in control. Fortunately, there was no dew to contend with"

Charitha Asalanka (Sri Lanka Skipper): "Certainly, we weren't up to the mark with the ball during the powerplay. However, we made a strong comeback, and at one point, it seemed they might reach 240. We could have performed better with the bat. The 6-5 combination is an experiment, but it's the approach we should consider for the future."

India Triumphs Over Sri Lanka in Rain-Shortened Thriller to seal the T20I series ! The Men in Blue showcased their prowess in an 8-over chase, defeating Sri Lanka by 7 wickets and with 9 balls to spare. Sri Lanka batting first, got off to a great start, with Pathum Nissanka's 32 and Kusal Perera's blistering 53 off 34 balls providing a strong foundation, after which Ravi Bishnoi shone with the ball for India claiming 3/26, supported by Axar Patel, Arshdeep Singh and Hardik Pandya, who each took two wickets to pull back the momentum and restrict Sri Lanka to 161/9.

Chasing a revised target of 78 runs in 8 overs, India came out with all guns blazing. Yashasvi Jaiswal set the tone with a rapid 30 off 15 balls, and despite losing Sanju Samson early, captain Suryakumar Yadav’s explosive 26 off 12 and Hardik Pandya’s unbeaten 22 off 9 balls sealed the victory for the Men in Blue.

 

Charith Asalanka, Sri Lanka Captain: "Disappointed with the way we batted at the death. This pitch gets tough to bat on as the ball gets older and as professional cricketers, we must do better. We were behind by 15-20 runs. The weather also played its part, and it's not easy to bowl 8 overs with a wet outfield."

 

Suryakumar Yadav, India Captain: "We spoke about this before the start of the tournament - the brand of cricket we want to play. This is the template we want to move forward with. Considering the weather, anything below 160 would have been nice. The rain helped us and the way the boys batted was wonderful. Very happy for the boys, they showed a lot of character in tough situations."

 

Ravi Bishnoi is the Player of the match

Ravi Bishnoi: "The pitch was a little different from yesterday. It was turning a bit and helping the spinners in the first innings. I stuck to my plans. It's a good responsibility to bowl in the death overs; it means the captain and the management trust me."

India and Sri Lanka are all set to play the final game of their three-match T20I series on July 30, 2024, at the Pallekele International Stadium.


With the series already sealed by India in the first two games, first by 43 runs and the second by seven wickets in a rain-curtailed-game,  they will now look to test their bench strength with different combinations and aim for a clean sweep. The Indian team has been in stupendous form with both bat and ball. Jaiswal's explosive starts and Suryakumar Yadav's versatile batting have been highlights, while Ravi Bishnoi has stood out as the leading bowler, ably supported by Arshdeep Singh and Riyan Parag. This first series under the combination of Gautam Gambhir and Suryakumar Yadav has already been a success, and they will be looking to end the series on a high note.
Sri Lanka, on the other hand, have struggled throughout the series, particularly their middle order, which collapsed significantly—losing nine wickets for 30 runs in the first game and seven wickets for 31 runs in the second game. However, their top order has been impressive, spearheaded by Nissanka's magnificent performances. Kusal Perera and Mendis have also shown good form with the bat. Pathirana has successfully dismissed Suryakumar Yadav in both games, and Hasaranga has taken Jaiswal's wicket in both matches. They will be keen to replicate their performances once again. Sri Lanka will be looking to change their middle-order fortunes and will eye a consolation win to end the series on a positive note.

Head-To-Head in T20Is:
In the 31 games played between the two teams, India has emerged Victorious on 21 occasions while Sri Lanka has managed to win nine games. One game ended with no result.



 

Pitch Report (Russel Arnold):

"A strong wind is blowing across the field, likely to clear away the concerning clouds, but we may still see intermittent showers. We're on a new pitch right next to the one used in the last two games. This surface is drier, with visible cracks, so expect a significant turn. Slower deliveries will be particularly effective here.

There's dew on the ground, making the ball wet and causing it to slide. As a result, chasing might be the preferable option. A target of 160-170 should be competitive. The slower you bowl, the more difficult it will be for batters to play their strokes. The dew will also make it challenging to grip the ball properly."

Toss:- Sri Lanka has won the toss and opted to bowl first.

Charith Asalanka: "We are going to bowl first. The pitch looks dry. There was a batting collapse when the ball got older, making it harder to bat. We've planned a bit differently this time. We have one change in the lineup, Wickramasinghe comes in for Dasun."

Suryakumar Yadav: "We would've liked to chase as well, considering the weather. It becomes difficult for the bowling team to control the ball later. We have four players resting today - Hardik, Axar, Rishabh, and Arshdeep. We talked about the brand of cricket we want to play, and it's about improving every game and being the best version of ourselves."

In a nail-biting encounter at the Pallekele International Cricket Stadium, India edged out Sri Lanka in a super over after the match ended in a tie. Both teams scored 137 in their allotted 20 overs, leading to the dramatic finish.

India, batting first, posted a total of 137/9. Despite early setbacks, Shubman Gill (39 off 37) and Riyan Parag (26 off 18) provided some stability. The standout bowler for Sri Lanka was Maheesh Theekshana, who took 3 wickets for 28 runs. Chamindu Wickramasinghe and Wanindu Hasaranga also contributed significantly, each taking crucial wickets to keep the Indian batting lineup in check.

Sri Lanka's chase saw a solid start from Kusal Mendis (43 off 41) and Kusal Perera (46 off 34), but they struggled to maintain momentum, losing wickets at critical junctures. Ravi Bishnoi and Washington Sundar were the pick of the Indian bowlers, each claiming two wickets to keep the pressure on while Rinku and Surya too contributed with two wickets. The match eventually ended in a tie, with Sri Lanka finishing at 137/8.

In the super over, India's bowlers held their nerve to secure a thrilling victory, sealing the series. This win marked a significant achievement for Suryakumar Yadav's leadership and highlighted the depth and resilience of the Indian team.

Washington Sundar | Player of the Match:
"All the work I've put in, along with blessings from God, really helped me today. I tried to stay calm throughout. I'm very grateful to SKY for trusting me with the ball. It's a wonderful opportunity, and I just focused on doing what I'm supposed to do. We did our homework on their batters, and I aimed to hit the right lengths."

Charith Asalanka: 
"I am really disappointed with our batting lineup, especially the middle-order and lower middle-order. The poor shot selection was a major issue. Hasaranga was sent up the order because the spinners were bowling, and he had the license to hit a few boundaries, but it didn't work out. We made wrong shot selections on this pitch. The target was definitely achievable, and we need to perform better as professional cricketers. I want to see improved batting performances in the ODIs. Our top three and four have done well, which is the only positive for us."

Suryakumar Yadav | Player of the Series:
"More than the last over, I feel the real turning point was when we were 30/4. The boys showed incredible character to reach 140, which was a par score on that track. I told them that if we put our hearts into it, we could pull it off. Their skill level and self-confidence make my job easy. The positivity and care they have for each other are unbelievable. After the last game, I told a few boys they would be rested, and they were ready to sit out without hesitation. They make my job easy, and I feel little pressure when I bat. As I said before the series, I don't want to just be a captain; I want to be a leader."

PreMatchCommentary:
Ladies and gentlemen,brace yourselves for an electrifying showdown as India take on Sri Lanka in a thrilling three-match ODI series! Fresh off a 3-0 T20I sweep, the Men in Blue are ready to light up the R. Premadasa Stadium in Colombo.

With the return of heavyweights like Rohit Sharma, Virat Kohli, KL Rahul, and Shreyas Iyer, India’s lineup looks formidable. The top order, featuring Rohit and Shubman Gill, promises fireworks, while the middle order, bolstered by Iyer and Rahul, adds depth and stability. Keep an eye out for the potential debut of Riyan Parag, adding a fresh spark to the mix.

The bowling attack remains strong, with Axar Patel and Kuldeep Yadav leading the charge, and Harshit Rana poised for his maiden ODI appearance. Despite the gloomy weather forecast and a 78% chance of rain, the anticipation is palpable.

Sri Lanka, battling injury woes, will rely on the likes of Pathum Nissanka and Kusal Mendis to step up. But make no mistake, the spotlight is firmly on India as they aim to continue their dominance and fine-tune their squad ahead of the Champions Trophy. 


Head to Head
PostMatchCommentary:
Powerplay (1-10 Overs) :-

SL- 37/1 (3.7 rpo, 5x4, 0x6)  || IND- 71/0 (7.1 rpo, 9x4, 3x6)

Middle Overs (11-40 Overs) :- 

SL - 128/5 (4.2 rpo, 11x4, 3x6)  || IND- 125/6 (4.1 rpo, 11x4, 1x6)

Death Overs (41-50 Overs) :- 

SL- 65/2 (6.5 rpo, 7x4, 2x6)  || IND- 34/4 (4.5 rpo, 1x4, 2x6)

 

 

 

In a closely contested match, Sri Lanka posted a total of 230/8 in their 50 overs, with notable contributions from Pathum Nissanka (56), Dunith Wellalage (67*), and Wanindu Hasaranga (24). India's bowlers performed well, with Axar Patel and Arshdeep Singh each taking two wickets.

In response, India’s innings saw a strong start from Rohit Sharma, who scored 58, but consistent wickets from Sri Lanka's bowlers, particularly Wanindu Hasaranga (3/58) and Charith Asalanka (3/30), kept India in check. Despite contributions from Shivam Dube (24), Virat Kohli (24), and KL Rahul (31), India was bowled out for 230 in 47.5 overs, resulting in a tie.

 

 

Dunith Wellalage is Player of the Match

Dunith Wellalage: "I came with a plan knowing the wicket was turning. My goal was to put their bowlers under pressure. Janith and I aimed to build a partnership, and later, I had a solid partnership with Hasaranga. The wicket was slow, so we targeted a score of 220. The pitch improved slightly in the second innings. Our skipper Wanindu Hasaranga changed the game for us. Overall, we played a wonderful match today."

 

 

Rohit Sharma, India Skipper:  "The score was gettable, but it required good batting to reach it. We batted well in patches but lacked consistent momentum. We had the upper hand, but then we lost a couple of wickets. The partnership between KL and Axar brought us back into the game. It was a bit disappointing at the end, but these things happen. Sri Lanka played well, and in the end, it was a fair result. The pitch remained the same; it wasn't one where you could just come in and play your shots—you had to dig in. The game swung back and forth between both teams. We should have managed to get that one run."

 

 

 

Charith Asalanka, Sri Lanka Skipper: "I did believe we could defend the total; we should have done a bit better to restrict them. The pitch turned more in the afternoon, but under lights, batting became easier. When the left-hander came in, I felt I could bowl as it was spinning a lot. I'm happy with the energy we showed in the field. Dunith's knock was crucial, and Nissanka batted well."

TossDetails: Sri Lanka Won The Toss And Elected To Bat

PreMatchCommentary:
Following an exhilarating opener in the ODI series, we are back for the second match between India and Sri Lanka. The venue remains unchanged, but the hosts will be missing their star player, Wanindu Hasaranga, due to a hamstring injury from the previous game. The Indian team, which dominated much of the first match, aims to rectify their past errors. Meanwhile, the spirited Sri Lankan side seeks to maintain the momentum they gained in the latter stages of the first ODI. 

 

 

PITCH REPORT: 
Russell Arnold: "It's a scorching afternoon, and the warm breeze adds to the heat. We've shifted a few strips over, and the pitch looks dry, much like the one from a couple of days ago. The cracks on the surface are quite wide, indicating significant crumbling as the game progresses. The captain who wins the toss will likely choose to bat first. Batters will need to focus on finding the gaps and running hard to wear down the opposition."

 

 

TOSS:
Sri Lanka has won the toss and has elected to first

 

 

Charith Asalanka, Sri Lanka Skipper: "Definitely we are batting first. The pitch appears similar to the previous match with minimal changes. Our strategy remains unchanged from the last game. Wanindu Hasaranga and Mohamed Shiraz are out, replaced by Kamindu Mendis and Jeffrey Vandersay. The previous game gave us a boost, and now we need to capitalize on that and secure a win."

 

 

Rohit Sharma, India Skipper:  "We understand what's required when chasing, so we've talked to the team about it. You can't always approach the game with the same mindset; you need to adjust to the conditions at hand. We've emphasized this to the boys. It's crucial to adapt quickly and play with freedom. Staying focused on the present and what needs to be done today is important. We're going with the same XI. As for the tie, it wasn't a blow to morale. Analyzing the game, both teams dominated at different stages, making it a fair outcome in the end."
PostMatchCommentary:
