SL- 79/3 (7.9 rpo, 6x4, 2x6)  || IND- 8/2 (3.6 rpo, 0x4, 0x6)

 

 

Sri Lanka defeated India by 32 runs. Batting first, Sri Lanka scored 240-9, with notable contributions from Avishka Fernando (40), Dunith Wellalage (39), and Kamindu Mendis (40). Washington Sundar and Kuldeep Yadav were the pick of the bowlers for India. In reply, India managed 208 in 42.2 overs, led by Rohit Sharma's 64 and Axar Patel's 44. Jeffrey Vandersay starred with the ball for Sri Lanka, taking 6 wickets for 36 runs, while Charith Asalanka chipped in with 3 wickets.

 

 

Jeffrey Vandersay is Player of the Match 

Jeffrey Vandersay: "There was a lot of pressure coming into the side, especially after a layoff. While it's easy to take credit for my performance, I want to acknowledge the batters who scored 240 runs, making it easier for me to bowl in good areas. With Hasaranga, our No. 1 spinner, out, I had to adapt to the team's atmosphere and balance quickly. I need to keep pushing myself to perform well."

 

Rohit Sharma, India Skipper:  "Losing a game is always painful; it's not just about those 10 overs. Consistency is key, and we didn't manage that today. While it's disappointing, these things happen. We need to adapt to the conditions in front of us. With a left-right combination, we thought it would be easier to rotate the strike—credit to Jeffrey Vandersay for his impressive six-wicket haul.  Don't want to look too much into how we played. But there'll be talks about our batting in the middle overs"

 

Charith Asalanka, Sri Lanka Skipper: "I was quite satisfied with our score of 240, which I felt was sufficient. As a captain, having an abundance of spin options is a good problem to have. Vandersay delivered an unbelievable spell, especially considering the opposition was over 90 runs when he started bowling. My primary role is as a batter, so I focus on scoring runs first, and then I can contribute with my bowling."

TossDetails: Sri Lanka Won The Toss And Elected To Bat
TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Bat
CompetitionName: India Tour Of Sri Lanka Odi Series 2024
PreMatchCommentary:
Greetings and a warm welcome to the live commentary of the third and final ODI between hosts Sri Lanka and India at R Premadasa International Stadium, Colombo. The ODI series has taken an intriguing turn after a dominant display in the T20I series, where India achieved a resounding whitewash. The first match ended in a dramatic tie, while the second match saw Sri Lanka emerging victorious.

Today's match is crucial, with everyone wondering: Will India level the series with a win, or will Sri Lanka secure a trophy for their cabinet? Another point of interest is India's playing XI - will there be any changes, or will they stick with the same team?

Stay tuned as we dive into this thrilling encounter.

Head to Head :

One match ended in a tie between the two nations. 

 

PITCH REPORT: 
Russell Arnold: "The pitch is dry once again, setting the stage for a similar type of game. However, it’s a fresh pitch, with the groundsman meticulously using scissors to remove grass. This has resulted in more visible cracks, promising not just a turn but also the occasional spiteful bounce. This will certainly present a greater challenge for the batters. To score runs here, one must adopt a patient and disciplined approach. As Robbie mentioned, you’ve got to be boring to get runs here."

 

TOSS:
Sri Lanka has won the toss and has elected to first

 

Charith Asalanka, Sri Lanka Skipper: " Definitely We are going to bat first. It looks the same as the previous two ODIs. Theekshana comes in for Akila Dananjaya. Guys are doing very well, we are in a good position. I would like to see someone score a hundred on this pitch."

 

Rohit Sharma, India Skipper: "Plenty to play for, and we've been challenged in the last two matches. It's clear what we need to do with both the bat and the ball. We've addressed it as a group. You have to give credit to the opposition; they played well and understood the situation perfectly. This is another opportunity for us to correct our course. We have two changes: Rishabh and Riyan Parag come in for KL and Arshdeep."
PostMatchCommentary:
Powerplay (1-10 Overs) :-
SL - 41/0 (4.10 rpo, 7x4, 0x6)  ll  IND - 67/3 (6.70 rpo, 12x4, 1x6)

Middle Overs (11-40 Overs) :- 
SL - 147/4 (4.9 rpo, 8x4, 5x6)  ll  IND - 71/7 in 16.1 overs (4.40 rpo, 6x4, 3x6)

Death Overs (41-50 Overs) :- 
SL -  60/3 (6.0 rpo, 4x4, 1x6)

 

 

Sri Lanka clinched a convincing victory by 110 runs. In their innings, they posted 248-7 in 50 overs. Key contributions came from Avishka Fernando, who scored a solid 96 off 102 balls, and Kusal Mendis, who added 59 off 82. Riyan Parag was the standout bowler for India, taking 3 wickets for 54 runs.

In reply, India's batting lineup crumbled, managing only 138 runs in 26.1 overs. Rohit Sharma top-scored with a quick 35 off 20 balls, but the rest of the batting order struggled against the Sri Lankan bowlers. Dunith Wellalage was particularly effective, claiming 5 wickets for just 27 runs, leading Sri Lanka to a dominant win. Sri Lanka win the series 2 to NIL and win a bilateral series against India after 27 years. 

 

 

Avishka Fernando is the Player of the Match 

Avishka Fernando: "I'm very happy with the innings. The batters came together and did a good job. It was a challenging wicket, and while I'm a bit disappointed not to get a hundred, I'm thrilled with the win."

 

 

Dunith Wellalage is Player of the Series 

Dunith Wellalage: "I want to thank my skipper, teammates, and coaching staff. Everyone gave me great support, and that's why I'm here. We adjusted well to the wicket as it was turning, similar to the first two ODIs, and committed fewer mistakes today. The batters did a great job, and then the spinners bowled exceptionally well. Everyone is supporting each other, and I am excited to be part of this team."

 

 

Rohit Sharma, India Skipper: "I don't think it's a major concern, but it's something we need to address individually and within our game plan. It's a joke to think that playing for India allows any room for complacency. When I am captain, complacency is not an option. However, you have to give credit where it's due—Sri Lanka played better than us today. We assessed the conditions and chose our combinations accordingly. Some players needed to be considered, hence the changes. We have many areas that need improvement, rather than just focusing on the positives."

 

 

Charith Asalanka, Sri Lanka Skipper: " I am a happy captain right now. The team did everything right throughout the series. We all knew India had a strong batting lineup, so we focused on our strength, which is spin, and we backed it fully. The team is in high spirits, and our coach, Sanath Jayasuriya, has been very active and supportive. The boys have really enjoyed the team environment."

TossDetails: Bangladesh Won The Toss And Elected To Field
TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Field
CompetitionName: Bangladesh Tour Of India Test Series 2024
PreMatchCommentary:
The Indian cricket team is gearing up for an intense and exciting three-month Test season, beginning with a two-match series against Bangladesh, starting on September 19, 2024, at the iconic MA Chidambaram Stadium in Chennai. This season promises to be a grueling one for India, as they will play a total of 10 Test matches—five at home and five away. After facing Bangladesh, India will take on New Zealand in another home series, followed by a crucial five-match series against Australia down under in November and December.
 

Bangladesh enters this contest with immense confidence, having just completed a historic series win against Pakistan on their home soil. This victory marks Bangladesh's third away Test series triumph, and it has come at a crucial time when they are still in contention for a spot in the World Test Championship (WTC) final.


The standout performers for Bangladesh in the Pakistan series were Litton Das and Mehidy Hasan Miraz, both of whom played pivotal roles while Mushfiqur Rahim's 191 in the first Tests was their key to victory. In a thrilling comeback during the second Test, Bangladesh was reduced to 26/6 in their first innings, trailing by more than 200 runs. However, Litton and Mehidy stitched together a record-breaking seventh-wicket partnership that turned the game around, ultimately leading Bangladesh to a convincing six-wicket victory.

Mehidy Hasan’s heroics were not limited to his batting. With the ball, he claimed 10 wickets across the two games, making him the leading wicket-taker in the series for Bangladesh. He was closely followed by Hasan Mahmud, who took 8 wickets, and the young pace sensation Nahid Rana, who grabbed 6 wickets. Bangladesh’s bowling attack, spearheaded by these players, will aim to carry this winning momentum into the series against India, with the WTC final spot still very much within reach.
 

India, on the other hand, returns to the international arena after a considerable break. The last time they played was in early August, and they will be keen to get back into the groove with a fresh start. India currently sits at the top of the WTC points table with 68.52 PCT in nine matches so far and has the most remaining matches (10) to play. With the stakes high, they are aiming to consolidate their position and make a strong case for the WTC final yet again.


The pitch at the MA Chidambaram Stadium, known for assisting spinners, will likely see India fielding a spin-heavy attack. The combination of local hero Ravichandran Ashwin and Ravindra Jadeja will form the crux of India’s bowling attack, supported by a third spinner. India may also go with two pacers to maintain a balanced lineup, with the possibility of including one of their young fast-bowling talents. The Chepauk wicket, traditionally known for its turn and variable bounce, will test both teams’ batting skills against high-quality spin.


India’s squad is a blend of experience and youth, and the team management will likely rely on their seasoned players to lead the charge. With senior players such as Ashwin and Jadeja handling the spin department, and experienced batters like Virat Kohli and Rohit Sharma in the middle, India will look to dominate Bangladesh from the outset.
 

A Battle with High Stakes

With both teams eyeing the WTC final, this series promises to be a fascinating contest. Bangladesh is riding high on their recent success and will be hungry to challenge the top-ranked side. For India, this is the beginning of a crucial season, and they will aim to start it on a high note, especially with a challenging tour of Australia looming later in the year.

Head-To-Head in Tests:

In the 13 games contested between the two teams, India have clearly dominated the contest with 11 wins while other two games has been ended in a draw. Bangladesh are yet to open their win account against India so far.



Stats At MA Chidambaram Stadium.

In the 34 matches played at this venue, teams batting first have won 12 times, while teams batting second have emerged victorious on 10 occasions. Eleven matches have ended in a draw, and one game resulted in a tie. Spinners have dominated at Chepauk, taking 584 wickets, while pacers have managed 381 wickets. Interestingly, only two Indian batters have scored triple centuries in Tests, and both of these remarkable feats were achieved at this ground. Notably, Virender Sehwag also has another triple century to his name, which he scored in Multan.




Pitch Report: Dinesh Karthik: 

This surface, reminiscent of the ones that saw Bedi and Prasanna weave their magic, hints at bounce and turn. As the match unfolds, expect the spinners to dominate proceedings increasingly.

However, residual moisture lurks beneath, offering early promise for the quicks. It brings to mind Kapil Dev's exploits here in the '80s.

The toss winner faces a crucial decision: exploit early conditions or bank on later deterioration. This evolving pitch could shift the balance between bat and ball, making for a compelling Test match narrative.






Toss- Bangladesh have Won the Toss and Opted to Field! 

Najmul Hossain Shanto-: "We'll bowl first. The pitch's moisture should favour our seamers early on. It's hard on top, but we expect movement. We've balanced experience with youth, fielding three pacers to capitalize on these conditions. This opening match sets the tone for our evolving strategy in the series".

Rohit Sharma-: "We'd have bowled too. Conditions look challenging - a test for batters. Our prep's been solid. While the 10-Test cycle looms, our focus is here and now. We're going with three seamers - Bumrah, Akash Deep, Siraj - backed by our spin duo, Ashwin and Jadeja. This attack gives us versatility to exploit the pitch as it evolves throughout the day".
PostMatchCommentary:
Day 1 
India: 339/6 ( 2.98 rpo, 37x4, 4x6 )

Day 2 
India: 37/4 ( 3.26 rpo, 6x4, 0x6 ) || Bangladesh: 149/10 (3.15 rpo, 20x4, 1x6 )

India: 81/3 ( 3.52 rpo, 10x4, 1x6)

Day 3
India: 206/1 (5.02 rpo, 22x4, 7x6) || Bangladesh: 158/4 (4.23 rpo, 16x4, 5x6)


Day 4
Bangladesh: 77/6 (3.10 rpo, 4x4, 0x6)

 

 

 

India secured a dominant victory by 280 runs in a Test match against Bangladesh. In the first innings, India posted a total of 376 runs, with significant contributions from Ravindra Jadeja (86), R. Ashwin (113), and Yashasvi Jaiswal (56). Bangladesh's bowling was led by Hasan Mahmud, who took 5 wickets. Bangladesh struggled in their first innings, being bowled out for 149, with Shakib (32) and Litton Das (22) being the top scorers. Jasprit Bumrah claimed 4 wickets, while Akash Deep, Siraj, and Ravindra Jadeja contributed with two each.

In the second innings, India declared at 287/4, with Shubman Gill's exceptional 119* and Pant’s quick 109 playing a key role. Chasing a daunting target, Bangladesh put up a slightly better fight in their second innings, managing 234, with skipper Najmul Hossain Shanto scoring 82 to lead the charge. However, Ashwin's 5-wicket haul ensured Bangladesh’s defeat, sealing the match in India’s favour by a comprehensive margin of 280 runs.

 

 

Najmul Hossain Shanto, Bangladesh Skipper: " Would like to concentrate on the positives.  Commendable bowling efforts from Hasan Mahmud, Taskin Ahmed, and Nahid Rana in the first innings. India batted well and their seamers contributed, especially with the new ball. Like we bowled in the first innings, We need momentum and keep delivering such performances consistently. As a Batter, my focus is on contributing by staying at the crease as long as possible without overthinking the result, which is key to the team's overall strategy."

 

 

Rohit Sharma, India Skipper: "It was a fantastic outcome considering what lies ahead for us. Even though we've been away from playing for a while, you're never truly away from cricket. We arrived a week in advance, aiming for the result we wanted. Pant has been terrific. He’s gone through some tough phases, and the way he handled himself was incredible to watch. After returning in the IPL, followed by a strong World Cup, he’s back in his favorite format. The key was to give him enough game time, and credit to him, he made an immediate impact. Regardless of conditions, we aim to build our team around that approach. Over the past few years, wherever we’ve played, we’ve ensured we had this as part of our strategy. Full credit to the players for stepping up when needed. The red-soil pitch always presents something unique, requiring patience. This was a surface where we needed to be patient with both bat and ball to keep them under pressure. Ash has been there throughout. He’s consistently reliable with both the ball and bat. Every time he’s involved, it’s a joy to watch—he’s never out of the game. He also enjoyed his time batting in the TNPL."

 

 

R ASHWIN is Player of the Match 

 

R ASHWIN: "Every time I play in Chennai, it’s an incredible experience for me. I’ve spent so many hours in those stands watching Test cricket and international matches. I’m probably enjoying my game now because of what I’m doing on the field. It was a chance to fight hard and dig deep. I kept things simple and I’m grateful to Jadeja for his support. It was a special innings, though it didn’t really hit me until the second day. My main job is bowling—that’s how I make a living. Batting, on the other hand, just comes naturally to me.."

TossDetails: India Won The Toss And Elected To Field

PreMatchCommentary:
The spotlight shifts to Kanpur's Green Park Stadium as India and Bangladesh prepare for the second and final Test of their series, starting Friday. With India holding a 1-0 lead after a commanding 280-run victory in Chennai, the hosts are eyeing a clean sweep while Bangladesh desperately seeks to level the series. However, the weather might play spoilsport, with rain forecast for the opening days, adding an element of unpredictability to the contest.

The pitch at Kanpur, traditionally a balanced surface, could throw a curveball this time.This uncertainty, coupled with the weather, has both teams on edge as they finalize their strategies. India, buoyed by their depth in Chennai despite quiet outings from Rohit Sharma and Virat Kohli, might bolster their spin attack by bringing in Axar Patel or Kuldeep Yadav. 

As the teams take the field, all eyes will be on key battles: India's top order against Bangladesh's new ball attack, and Bangladesh's batsmen facing India's potent spin trio. While India enters as firm favorites, Bangladesh are eager to prove their mettle. With World Test Championship points at stake, this match promises to be a gripping contest, provided the weather permits.

Head-To-Head in Tests:

In as many as 14 games battled between the two teams, India has won 12 games while Bangladesh are yet to open their win account. Two games between them has been ended in a draw.

10:00 AM IST:
TOSS UPDATE: India won the Toss and Elected to Field First 



 

Rohit Sharma | India Captain:
"We’ll bowl first. The conditions favor that decision, and the pitch seems a bit soft, so our aim is to take early wickets with the help of our seamers. There’s a bit of grass on the surface, which could help us.There were plenty of positives from the first Test. Although we didn’t start well with the bat, we recovered strongly, posted a competitive total, and our bowlers did their part. In the second innings, we batted even better and set a challenging target. Our bowlers once again rose to the occasion.I expect this match to be no different in terms of competitiveness. We’ll be tested, but our experience should help. We are going in with an unchanged side." 

 

Najmul Hossain Shanto | Bangladesh Captain:
"I would have preferred to bat first, so I’m pleased with this decision.It's a good opportunity for us. Our pace bowlers performed well in the last game, executing their plans effectively. If we can replicate that, we'll be in a strong position to secure a win. As a batter, it's crucial to convert starts into big scores. The encouraging thing is that most of us got off to good starts in the last game. Hopefully, we can post a solid total today.The pitch looks good for batting. Handling the new ball will be vital, and how we negotiate those early overs will be key.We’ve made 2 changes.
PostMatchCommentary:
Day 1
Bangladesh: 107/3 (3.05 rpo, 18x4, 0x6) 
 

DAY 2: The play called off due to rain


DAY 3: No play due to wet outfield
 

Day 4
Bangladesh: 126/7 (3.26 rpo, 21x4, 1x6) || India: 285/9 (8.22 rpo, 28x4, 11x6)
Bangladesh: 26/2 (2.36 rpo, 3x4, 0x6)

Day 5
Bangladesh: 120/8 (3.33 rpo, 20x4, 0x6) || India: 98/3 (5.65 rpo, 15x4, 1x6) 
 

In a remarkable turn of events, India secured a convincing 7-wicket victory over Bangladesh in the second Test at Green Park, Kanpur, completing a 2-0 series sweep. The win, achieved with more than a session to spare, seemed improbable after nearly three days were lost to rain and wet outfield conditions.

The match began with India winning the toss and electing to field, a rare choice for the team in home Tests. Bangladesh's first innings, interrupted by weather delays, saw Mominul Haque as the standout performer with an unbeaten century. However, his efforts were not enough to prevent the visitors from being dismissed for 233, with Jasprit Bumrah leading India's bowling attack.

India's response was nothing short of extraordinary. The hosts adopted an aggressive T20-style approach in their first innings, breaking records for the fastest team totals at various stages. Rohit Sharma set the tone with three sixes as his first scoring shots, while Yashasvi Jaiswal and KL Rahul contributed quick half-centuries. India declared at 285/9 in just 34.4 overs, establishing a 52-run lead.

Bangladesh's second innings crumbled under pressure from India's formidable bowling lineup. Despite resistance from Shadman Islam and Mushfiqur Rahim, the visitors were bundled out for 146. Ravindra Jadeja, Jasprit Bumrah, and Ravichandran Ashwin shared the spoils, each claiming three wickets.

Chasing a modest target of 95, India lost early wickets but remained in control. Yashasvi Jaiswal once again showcased his aggressive intent, scoring a brisk 51 off 45 balls. Fittingly, Rishabh Pant hit the winning boundary, sealing India's victory.

This win solidifies India's position at the top of the World Test Championship standings and marks a successful start to Gautam Gambhir's tenure as coach. The team's ability to force a result in such time-constrained circumstances highlights their dominance in home conditions and their commitment to pursuing victory against all odds.

The match will be remembered for India's bold strategy and execution, turning what could have been a dull draw into a thrilling contest. 

 

Yashasvi Jaiswal (Player of the Match):
"I was just focused on what I could do for the team. The conditions in Chennai and here were different, so I adapted accordingly and gave my best. Every innings is important, and I always prepare with that mindset. Rohit bhai and Gautam sir told me to bat freely, and that’s exactly what we aimed for—to win and play with intent."

Najmul Hossain Shanto (Bangladesh Captain):
"We took early wickets but couldn’t capitalize later. In both matches, we didn't bat well according to the conditions. Our batters got starts but didn’t convert. Mominul's innings and Miraz’s bowling were positives, and I hope Miraz can continue this form in future matches."

Rohit Sharma (India Captain):
"In life, we all move on. Rahul Bhai did a great job, and now we’re working with Gambhir, who has a clear mindset. It’s early, but we’ve started well. Losing a couple of days meant we had to keep the game moving. After getting them out for 233, it wasn’t about runs but how many overs we could bowl at them. The pitch didn’t offer much, but the bowlers made it happen.We took a calculated risk by batting aggressively, even knowing we might get bowled out quickly. Akash Deep has the fitness and energy to bowl long spells, and it's important to have players ready when needed."

TossDetails: India Won The Toss And Elected To Field
TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Field
CompetitionName: Bangladesh Tour Of India T20 Series 2024
PreMatchCommentary:
India is set to kick off an exciting T20I series against Bangladesh in Gwalior with a fresh approach, as Suryakumar Yadav leads a young squad packed with new faces. The series marks the international debut for IPL stars Mayank Yadav and Harshit Rana, while Sanju Samson gets a new role as opener alongside Abhishek Sharma. With regular players rested, this series offers a golden opportunity for India's next generation to shine on the big stage.

Bangladesh, still recovering from their Test series loss, brings experience to the table despite missing Shakib Al Hasan. Led by Najmul Hossain Shanto, the visitors will rely on the skills of Mustafizur Rahman and Mehidy Hasan to challenge India's dominance in T20Is, where the hosts hold a commanding 13-1 head-to-head record. As both teams face off on Gwalior's new pitch, fans can expect an entertaining clash between India's youthful energy and Bangladesh's seasoned performers, making this series opener a must-watch event.

 

Pitch Report | Abhinav Mukund:
"The square boundaries measure 64 and 65 meters, typical of Indian grounds with black soil pitches. Although the grass looks dry, the pitch appears firm, offering the potential for runs. This being the first international game at this venue, local T20 matches here have seen plenty of runs, with teams chasing winning 8 out of 12 times. The team winning the toss will likely choose to field, given these conditions."

 

TOSS UPDATE: India Won the Toss and Elected to Field First  

 

Suryakumar Yadav | India Captain:
"We'll bowl first. It feels a bit humid, but I don't expect much change in conditions. It's great to be back in India, and there's a lot of talent in this group. The guys are eager to learn and perform. The crowd looks fantastic, and the pitch seems good too, so we're excited to get going. A few players deserve their opportunities today. Tilak Varma, Ravi Bishnoi, and Harshit Rana will miss out."
 

Najmul Hossain Shanto | Bangladesh Captain:
"We're fielding a fresh side with some new faces coming in for the T20Is. The pitch looks fresh, and while I would've liked to bowl first too, I hope our openers can set the tone. We're going with three seamers, two spinners, and a lineup of six batters."

Middle Overs (7-15 Overs) : BAN- 63/5(7 rpo, 5x4, 2x6) || India: 61/1 (10.45 rpo, 6x4, 3x6)
Death Overs (16-20 Overs) : BAN- 25/3(5.17 rpo, 0x4, 0x6) 



The Men in Blue, led by the swashbuckling Suryakumar Yadav, have stamped their authority on this series, taking a 1-0 lead with the subtlety of a sledgehammer!
Bangladesh, put into bat, found themselves in a whirlwind of Indian bowling brilliance. Arshdeep Singh and Varun Chakravarthy, both snaring 3 wickets apiece, spun a web so complex even Spider-Man would be jealous! The Tigers could only muster a meagre 127, with Mehidy Hasan Miraz's 35 being the lone bright spot.
But the real fireworks came in India's chase. It wasn't a chase, it was a demolition! Suryakumar Yadav's 29 off 14 set the tone, but it was Hardik Pandya who stole the show with a blistering 39 off 16. The target? Hunted down in just 11.5 overs! India romped home with 49 balls to spare, leaving Bangladesh scratching their heads. If this is a sign of things to come, buckle up folks, we're in for a rollercoaster ride in this series! 

 

Najmul Hossain Shanto | Bangladesh Captain:
"Yes, obviously, we didn’t start well at all. In T20Is, the first six overs are crucial, and we struggled with our batting. The plan was to play positively from the start, and show intent, but sometimes we need to mix that with sensible cricket. We didn’t plan well in that regard, and it’s something we’ll need to address in our team meeting. I feel we didn’t post enough runs. Rishad and Mustafizur bowled well, but unfortunately, we just didn’t put enough runs on the board to defend."  

 

Suryakumar Yadav | India Captain:
"We just focused on backing our skills, and what we discussed in the team meeting worked out well. That was the key. Absolutely, the way everyone showed character on the field was really promising. Every player stepped up, which made a big difference. It was pretty exciting to see them(Mayank Yadav and Nitish Reddy) perform. I’m really looking forward to watching them excel in the upcoming games. Honestly, it's a good problem to have as captain because at times I found it tough to decide whom to bowl, but every time I handed over the ball, the bowlers delivered. I’m really happy with how it went."



Arshdeep Singh | Player of the Match:
"There was some breeze from the end I was bowling, so I thought I’d use that to my advantage. I’m enjoying my cricket right now. I’ve made a few small adjustments in my run-up and wrist position, just trying to get better with every game. Experience plays a big part—the more you play, the better you understand the game. I loved the way everyone bowled today, especially Mayank. He was impressive."

TossDetails: Bangladesh Won The Toss And Elected To Field
TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Field
CompetitionName: Bangladesh Tour Of India T20 Series 2024
PreMatchCommentary:
India and Bangladesh are all set to ignite the crowd in Delhi on October 9, 2024, for what promises to be an electrifying second T20I. Team India, riding high on the back of a thrashing win in the first game, will be brimming with confidence. Their chase of a modest 128 was nothing short of a masterclass, finishing the job with 49 balls to spare. Fans were treated to some scintillating shots from the flamboyant Suryakumar Yadav, while Sanju Samson’s calm brilliance and Hardik Pandya’s blistering finish had Indian supporters roaring with joy.


But before the fireworks with the bat, it was the Indian bowlers who lit up the stage. Varun Chakaravarthy, returning to the fold, was on fire with a sensational three-wicket haul. Arshdeep Singh matched his intensity, also grabbing three crucial wickets, while debutant Mayank Yadav’s fearsome spell left Bangladesh reeling.


Bangladesh, however, will be itching for revenge. Their performance in the first game left fans disappointed, with only Mehidy Hasan’s fighting 35* and Najmul Hossain Shanto’s 27 standing out. Their bowlers were left clueless against India’s onslaught. But a comeback is on the cards, as they’ll be looking to pull off an upset and keep the series alive before heading to Hyderabad for the third T20I. Who among the two will come on top?

Head-To-Head in T20Is:
 



Stats at Arun Jaitley Stadium (Last five games)

In the last five games played here at this venue, the team batting first has won all five games, while the average first-batting score is 235. This is a batting paradise, and the team winning the toss will opt to bat first. It's a high-scoring affair on the cards. 

Pitch Report: Abinav Mukund

"The second T20 International is shaping up to be a high-scoring affair. Historically, this pitch has seen plenty of runs. It's not a particularly large ground - around 55-60m square and 70m straight. During the IPL, this pitch has consistently produced scores over 200. The surface looks hard, which could spell trouble for bowlers. We might even see scores above 200 prove insufficient. In a recent local T20 tournament, a team scored 300 runs here. Interestingly, teams batting first have a perfect record in IPL matches at this venue. While batting first seems advantageous, the presence of dew could be a factor to consider."

Toss: Bangladesh has won the toss and elected to field! 

Najmul Hossain Shanto:-
"We would prefer to bowl first. There's a chance of dew in the second innings. The pitch looks good for batting, with high scores in previous matches. We need to focus on our strengths today. Our top order must perform well in the powerplay. We've made one change: Sakib is replacing Shoriful in the lineup."

Suryakumar Yadav:- 
"We wanted to bat first too. It's a chance to test our bowlers with a potentially wet ball. There's plenty of talent in the team. I'm enjoying watching our batters perform. You need to stay ahead of the game. The pitch looks great. We're going with the same lineup as last time."
PostMatchCommentary:

India secured the series 2-0 with an emphatic 86-run win in the second T20I, dominating both with the bat and ball. Put into bat first on Delhi's batting-friendly pitch, India posted a formidable 221/9 in their 20 overs. Nitish Reddy and Rinku Singh were the standout performers, each scoring crucial half-centuries, while Hardik Pandya provided the finishing touch with some powerful hitting at the death.

Chasing a challenging target of 222, Bangladesh struggled to build any momentum, regularly losing wickets throughout the innings. They eventually finished at 135/9, with Mahmudullah top-scoring with 41. For India, Nitish Reddy and CV Varun picked up two wickets each, while the rest of the bowling attack chipped in with a wicket apiece, sealing the comprehensive win and the series victory for India.

Najmul Hossain Shanto- Bangladesh Skipper
"We repeated our mistakes from the previous game, which isn't acceptable for our team. We must improve. Bowling first was the right call, I believe. Their batting picked up after the powerplay, and we struggled to stick to our plans. As batsmen, we need to step up and have more self-belief. Our bowlers performed well, but we couldn't break through in the middle overs."

Suryakumar Yadav -India Skipper
"I welcomed that scenario, wanting our middle-order batsmen in that position. I'm pleased with both Rinku and Nitish. They played exactly as I'd hoped. It's about going out there and expressing yourself. Only the jersey changes, everything else stays the same. I was keen to see how different bowlers would handle various situations."

Nitish Kumar Reddy - Player Of The Match
"It's an incredible feeling to play for India. I'm proud and grateful for this opportunity. Credit goes to the captain and coach for their support. They gave me the freedom to play my game. I started cautiously, but after that no-ball, things went my way."

TossDetails: India Won The Toss And Elected To Bat
TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Bat
CompetitionName: Bangladesh Tour Of India T20 Series 2024
PreMatchCommentary:
As Team India gears up for the T20I series finale at Hyderabad's Rajiv Gandhi International Stadium, they're not just eyeing a clean sweep – they're scripting a cricketing blockbuster!

Having already pocketed the series with stellar shows in Gwalior and Delhi, the Men in Blue are now on a mission to test their bench strength. It's like a cricket version of "India's Got Talent," and boy, have we uncovered some gems!

Take Nitish Kumar Reddy, for instance. This lad didn't just debut; he exploded onto the scene like a bat-wielding firecracker in Delhi. And let's not forget Rinku Singh, the ultimate supporting actor who's threatening to steal the show.

Together, they propelled India to a massive 221/9 in the second match, leaving Bangladesh's bowlers feeling like they'd been caught in a batting blitzkrieg. Poor Taskin Ahmed and Mustafizur Rahman – they flashed moments of brilliance, but mostly looked like they were trying to stop a runaway train with a cricket bat.

Now, as we head into the Hyderabad humdinger, the pitch promises more fireworks than Diwali. With a par score of 171, we might need to install a scoreboard with extra digits!

Sure, there's a whiff of rain in the air, but nothing can dampen Team India's spirits.So, will it be a hat-trick of wins for India? Or will Bangladesh find their roar in the eleventh hour? 


TOSS UPDATE: India Won the Toss and Elect to Bat First 
 

Suryakumar Yadav | India Captain:
"We've decided to bat first. The wicket looks good, and with the dew factor in mind, we want to challenge ourselves. It's fantastic to see so many supporters here, even with us leading 2-0.Maintaining the approach we've had in the last two games is important—building strong habits is key. We're focused on allowing players to express themselves on the field. We've made one change today: Arshdeep Singh is out, and Ravi Bishnoi comes in."


Najmul Hossain Shanto | Bangladesh Captain:
"Yes, I’m happy to be bowling first, so the toss doesn’t really matter. We’ve made two changes. Mehidy Hasan is in and Jaker Ali is out. Mahedi Hasan and Tanzid Hasan come into the XI."
PostMatchCommentary:

In a stunning display of batting prowess, India dominated Bangladesh with a massive 297/6 in their 20 overs, securing a 133-run victory in this T20 match.

Sanju Samson's remarkable 111 off just 47 balls electrified the stadium. With eleven fours and eight sixes, the wicketkeeper-batsman showcased his exceptional form, with a strike rate of 236.17. Not to be outdone, Captain Suryakumar Yadav's 75 off 35 balls demonstrated his T20 batting mastery, solidifying his reputation as one of the most formidable batsmen in this format.

Riyan Parag (34 off 13) and Hardik Pandya (47 off 18) then unleashed a fierce onslaught in the final overs, pummeling the boundary rope. Bangladesh's bowler Tanzim Hasan Sakib picked up three wickets but conceded 66 runs in 4 overs, leaving their entire bowling unit reeling from India's relentless attack.

Bangladesh's response fell short, with Parvez Hossain Emon dismissed for a golden duck, setting the tone for their innings. Despite Towhid Hridoy's resilient 63* and Litton Das's brisk 42, they never seemed to be in contention. Ravi Bishnoi was India's standout bowler, claiming 3 wickets for 30 runs in 4 overs, choking the Bangladesh middle order. Mayank Yadav's pace proved too much to handle, and Varun Chakravarthy's economical 4-0-23-0 maintained the pressure throughout.

In the end, Bangladesh's 164/7 was insufficient. India's dominant performance highlighted their strength in both batting and bowling. While questions may arise about Bangladesh's strategy, for now, India can revel in their well-deserved victory and the confidence it brings. 

 

Najmul Hossain Shanto | Bangladesh Captain:
"We didn’t play our best cricket today. We didn’t execute our batting plans, and with the ball, we were good in patches but overall didn’t bowl well enough.We need to believe in ourselves, and the players have to keep working on their game. I thought Hridoy batted well today, and the seamers executed their plans nicely. However, the top-order batsmen really need to improve  
 

Sanju Samson | Player Of The Match :
"Our dressing room is full of positive energy, and I’m happy the team is celebrating my success. It can be frustrating at times, knowing what you're capable of, and I've always felt I could do more. But with experience, I’ve learned to handle pressure and deal with failures since I’ve faced them a lot.My focus was on sticking to the process and trusting that I’d perform. There’s always pressure when playing for your country, but I wanted to deliver. I kept things simple, taking it one ball at a time. The leadership has shown immense faith in me, not just with words but through their actions as well."  
 

Hardik Pandya | Player Of The Series :
"The freedom the skipper and coach have given us is really benefiting everyone in the team. It’s allowing us to bring out the best in each other. When you enjoy each other’s success, it creates a hunger to do even more. Physically, I’m feeling good, and I’m grateful for that. That shot over covers, off the back foot, was just a chip that cleared the ropes—one of my favourites because it’s not something you pull off every day." 
 

Suryakumar Yadav | India Captain:
"I think we've achieved a lot as a team. I had mentioned that we wanted to build a team of selfless cricketers, and we’re seeing that happen, with everyone enjoying each other’s performances. The camaraderie is really showing. As Gauti bhai said before the series, no one is bigger than the team—whether you're on 49 or 99, you still have to go for the big shot. That's exactly what Sanju did today.We need to stay flexible with both batting and bowling, and it’s great to see bowlers stepping up when needed and batters being adaptable. Their performances were commendable. In terms of improvement, we just need to keep up the good habits on the field and remain consistent."

CompetitionName: New Zealand Tour Of India Test Series 2024
PreMatchCommentary:
The Men in Blue are set to return to Test cricket with a three-match series against New Zealand, kicking off at the M. Chinnaswamy Stadium in Bengaluru. Fresh off a dominant victory over Bangladesh in both T20Is and Tests, India are brimming with confidence as they inch closer to securing a spot in the World Test Championship (WTC) final. With a near-unchanged lineup, the home side is looking to continue their impressive form on familiar turf.

India has a clear advantage. Their squad, led by Rohit Sharma, Virat Kohli and the lethal spin duo of Ravichandran Ashwin and Ravindra Jadeja, is a force to be reckoned with—especially at home. The return of pace ace Jasprit Bumrah adds even more firepower to India’s bowling attack. With only three more wins needed from their remaining eight Tests to secure a WTC final berth, the hosts are in a strong position.

For New Zealand, the absence of Kane Williamson leaves a significant gap in their batting lineup. However, the Kiwis will need more than individual heroics to challenge India’s depth and form.

Weather could play a role, with rain expected in Bengaluru. If the pitch becomes seamer-friendly, New Zealand might find some respite by putting India into bat under cloudy skies. But even wet conditions are unlikely to shake India’s confidence, given their well-rounded squad.

Head-To-Head In Tests:

In 62 Test matches between India and New Zealand, India has claimed victory 22 times, while New Zealand has won 13 matches. The remaining 27 games ended in draws. On Indian soil, the two teams have clashed in 36 Tests, with India winning 17 and New Zealand managing only 2 wins. Notably, the Kiwis' last victory in India dates back to 1988, highlighting India's dominance at home over the past few decades.

 

Did You Know?

The Last Time NZ defeated India in Tests in India, Ajaz Patel was less than 40 days old, and other New Zealand players from the current squad were not born!
New Zealand have never defeated India in Bengaluru in their six attempts so far! 


8:57 AM IST: The Toss has been Delayed due to Rain

11:00 AM IST: It's Still Drizzling at Bengaluru and the wait continues!

11:30 AM IST: That Will be Lunch On Day 1!

1:10 PM IST: Just when it seemed like the rain had eased, it’s back again

2:00 PM IST: And... unfortunately, the covers are back on as the drizzles have returned. It looks like we'll have to wait a bit longer.

2:10 PM IST: The Second Session is also washed out fully and it will be Tea on day 1! 

2:30 PM IST : Play on Day 1 Has been Called off  



Day 2  |  8:15 AM IST: The Weather seems fine, We will have the Toss at 8:45 AM and Play will begin at 9:15 AM IST



 


Toss- India won the toss and elected to bat first! 



Rohit Sharma | India Captain:
We’re going to bat first. The pitch has been under covers and might be a bit sticky early, but it’s important to put runs on the board. We’ve been playing well in recent Tests. This is a fresh series, and we want to start strong. Two changes from the last Test—Gill misses out, Sarfaraz comes in. Kuldeep replaces Akash.
 

Tom Latham | New Zealand:
The wicket's been under covers, so hopefully we can use that to our advantage early with the ball. There's been some weather around, so our prep hasn’t been ideal. We’re going with three seamers alongside Ajaz Patel, and we have two all-rounders who can bowl spin as well.

Day 2, 
IND:- 46/10 (1.46 rpo, 4x4,0x6) || NZ- 180/3 (3.6 rpo, 22x4, 3x6)

NZ- 222/7 (5.42 rpo, 22x4, 9x6)  || IND:- 231/3 (4.71 rpo, 29x4,5x6)

IND:- 231/7 (4.57 rpo, 24x4,5x6) || NZ- 0/0 (0 rpo, 0x4, 0x6) 

Day - 5
NZ- 110/2 (4.44 rpo, 16x4, 1x6)   
 

New Zealand defeated India by 8 wickets in the first test of a three-match series, marking their first test victory in India in 36 years. India, choosing to bat first, was dismissed for a record-low home score of 46 runs. Matt Henry led the bowling attack with figures of 5/15.New Zealand responded with 402, featuring Rachin Ravindra's maiden test century (134) and Devon Conway's 91. Tim Southee contributed a quick 65.India's second innings saw a remarkable turnaround, scoring 462. Sarfaraz Khan (150) and Rishabh Pant (99) formed a crucial 177-run partnership. However, India collapsed, losing their last 7 wickets for just 54 runs.Chasing 107, New Zealand reached the target comfortably, with Will Young (48*) and Rachin Ravindra (39*) guiding them home despite early wickets from Jasprit Bumrah (2/29).The win gives New Zealand a 1-0 lead in the series 

 

Rohit Sharma | India Captain:
"We batted well in the second innings, especially after struggling in the first. A couple of guys stood up when needed, and that put us back in the game. Being 350 runs behind, we had to focus on playing each ball and building partnerships. It was a great effort not to fold under pressure.
 Both (Sarfaraz and Pant)  are batting heroes. Rishabh takes risks, but they pay off—it was a mature innings from him. Sarfaraz, in just his fourth Test, showed great maturity too. When you're clear-headed, things fall into place.
I knew overcast conditions would be tough, but I didn’t expect us to be bowled out for under 50. Full credit to New Zealand for bowling brilliantly. These things happen, but we’ll take the positives and move forward. We’ve bounced back before, like we did against England, and we’re ready for the next game." 
 

Tom Latham | New Zealand Captain:
"We were considering batting first too, so it was a good toss to lose. The bowlers hit the right areas and bowled India out cheaply, which set things up for us. We knew India would come hard in the second innings, but we bowled well with the second new ball to finish the job. Honestly, I never expected that. The bowlers did a great job, and the conditions helped us, but full credit to the team. Rachin and Southee’s partnership with the bat was also crucial for building a solid lead He’s been fantastic, troubling us in the nets with his extra bounce and pace. Having Tim Southee’s experience alongside him was brilliant. Rachin was outstanding with the bat, setting the tone beautifully. He’s shown his class over the last year, and we’re lucky to have him on our side. 
 

Rachin Ravindra | Player of the Match:
"It’s a nice city and a good wicket to bat on. It’s about having clarity in what needs to be done, and preparation helps. I’ve worked on playing on different surfaces—red soil, black soil, and against various types of bowlers. I was fortunate to get those facilities in Chennai. I wouldn’t say I’m looking to attack, but I focus on scoring when possible. The support has been amazing, and it’s great to have family backing me, I enjoyed my time coming out here and playing"

CompetitionName: New Zealand Tour Of India Test Series 2024
PreMatchCommentary:
India returns to the Maharashtra Cricket Association Stadium in Pune for the second Test against New Zealand, eager to bounce back after a rare home defeat. The pitch, with lower bounce and more turn, plays perfectly into India’s strengths, offering an ideal platform for their world-class spinners.Rohit Sharma’s team has made a key addition with Washington Sundar, who adds depth to the attack. Meanwhile, Rishabh Pant, after his outstanding partnership with Sarfaraz Khan in Bengaluru, is fully fit and ready for action.India’s shock first-innings collapse in the opening Test, where they were bowled out for 46, was followed by a spirited fightback, but New Zealand’s disciplined bowling, led by Tim Southee, sealed the win.All eyes are on Rohit's men to demonstrate the cricket that has made them a powerhouse in home conditions. With their wealth of talent, strategic depth, and home advantage, Team India stands ready to produce another memorable performance in their history.

Pitch Report: 
The surface composition is consistent—black soil characteristics are seen at both venues, Bangalore and Pune. Looking at the crucial good length zone, we're seeing significantly less moisture and minimal grass cover. With these conditions, batting first would be the optimal choice for whoever wins the toss, and spinners should find assistance right from the start. 






Toss:- New Zealand won the toss and elected to bat first.



Tom Latham:
We've chosen to bat first today. The wicket looks somewhat changed from our previous game - much less grass coverage out there. We're anticipating the ball to turn, which is typical when playing in this region. It's been a tremendously special achievement for our squad, and while we took time to enjoy that milestone, we're now completely focused on our game here in Pune. Matt Henry misses due to niggle while Santner replaces him in the squad.


Rohit Sharma:
We Would have preferred to bat first as well. That first Test was challenging - the opening session didn't work in our favor, but our second innings batting showed real character. There are positive takeaways from that match which we'll look to build on here. It's crucial to find momentum when you're on the back foot in Test cricket, and that's exactly what we managed. The surface is looking quite dry. We recognize the critical importance of those initial 10 overs. We're making three changes to our lineup - we'll be without Siraj, KL and Kuldeep today. Akash Deep, Washington and Gill will take their places.
PostMatchCommentary:
Day 1:- 
NZ - 259/10 ( 3.27rpo, 25x4, 3x6) || IND 16/1 ( 1.45rpo, 4x4, 0x6)
 

Day 2:-  
IND - 140/6 ( 4.95 rpo, 10x4 , 5x6) || NZ - 198/5 ( 3.73 rpo, 20x4, 1x6) 

Day 3:-  
NZ - 57/5 ( 3.42rpo, 4x4, 1x6) || IND 245/10 ( 4.60rpo, 24x4, 4x6) 

 

New Zealand etched their name in the history books with their first-ever series win in India, clinching the second Test by 113 runs. Winning the toss and opting to bat first, New Zealand put up a competitive total of 259 runs, thanks to crucial half-centuries from Rachin Ravindra and Devon Conway. India's spinners dominated, with Washington Sundar claiming seven wickets and R Ashwin taking three.

In response, the Indian batting lineup struggled against New Zealand’s spinners, particularly Mitchell Santner, who delivered a masterclass by taking seven wickets. India was bowled out for a mere 156, with Yashasvi Jaiswal and Shubman Gill both scoring 30. Trailing by 103 runs, New Zealand built on their lead, scoring 255 in their second innings. Tom Latham led the charge with a resilient 86, setting India a challenging target of 359 runs. Sundar continued his good form with four wickets.

Chasing 359, India was dismissed for 245. Santner once again proved to be India’s nemesis, picking up another five-wicket haul. Despite Jaiswal’s fighting knock of 77, India fell short. With this victory, New Zealand sealed the series 2-0, with one match remaining.


Rohit | India captain: 
Disappointing. It's not what we expected. Got to give credit to NZ - they played better than us. We failed to capitalise on certain moments. We failed to respond to those challenges. And we sit here today. Didn't think we batted well enough to get runs on the board. You've got to pick 20 wickets to win, yes, but batters have to put runs on the board. Was a great fightback to restrict them to 250-odd but we knew it was going to be challenging. When they started off, they were 200/3 and for us to come back and get them bowled out for 259 was a great effort. Wasn't a pitch where a lot was happening. We just didn't bat well enough. Things would've been slightly different had we got a bit closer in the first innings. We want to show up well at Wankhede and try and win that Test. It's a collective failure. I'm not somebody who would blame just the batters or the bowlers. We will come out with better intent, better ideas and better methods at Wankhede.

Latham | NZ captain: 
Really special feeling. Proud to be in this position. Whole team effort and a clear example of everyone pitching in. When you come over here you want to put your best foot forward. Putting runs on the board at the start was really important. Have to mention Mitch Santner. He was fantastic. Has been around the group a long time, and to finally get a break and bowl the way he has - credit to him. It was about trying to stick to our basics and play the long game. Both surfaces have been different, we've needed to adapt and we've done that very well. The method we played with last night - to put ourselves on the front foot - was terrifc. The way GP played this morning was really important. We knew India were going to come out hot. Didn't realise they were going to come that hot, but we managed to get the breakthroughs in the middle session. Those last two wickets took an age but when Tim took that catch we were really happy.


Santner | Player of the Match:
My approach stayed pretty consistent (in second innings). The conditions were a bit more challenging this time around. Have to acknowledge India's aggressive intent - it was probably the best way to play on that surface. We just maintained our discipline throughout. My body's feeling it now, especially the side after that extended spell of 20-plus overs. But in those moments, you just want to keep pushing through. Each wicket gave me a boost of energy. Really satisfied to have played my part in the team's success. Securing a series win here in India is something special - it's such a tough achievement. Taking wickets definitely helps build your confidence. As spinners, our focus is always on consistency - hitting those same spots repeatedly while mixing up the pace subtly - that's the foundation of our bowling unit's approach.

TossDetails: New Zealand Won The Toss And Elected To Bat
TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Bat
CompetitionName: New Zealand Tour Of India Test Series 2024
PreMatchCommentary:
India heads into the third Test at Wankhede determined to restore pride and protect their position in the World Test Championship standings. Facing an uncharacteristic 2-0 deficit at home, the team will look to rally under captain Rohit Sharma to end the series on a high. Despite setbacks in Bengaluru and Pune, India has shown resilience and will aim to bring that intensity to Mumbai.

New Zealand’s success has been a testament to their preparation and persistence, with bowlers like Mitchell Santner and Ajaz Patel rising to the occasion. However, India’s own spinners are primed for the Wankhede pitch, known for its bounce and turn, which could tilt conditions in the hosts’ favor.

India’s top order will be eager to set a strong foundation and put pressure on New Zealand, while the bowlers look to apply a decisive impact. Though the series may be out of reach, the team remains focused on delivering a performance that upholds their high standards and ensures vital WTC points. Expect an intense contest as India seeks to close out the series with renewed determination.

Toss:- New Zealand won the toss and elected to bat first. 

 

 

Tom Latham | New Zealand Captain: "We will bat first. It looks a good surface. Hopefully, we can put some runs on the board. Focusing on this Test. We did well in Bengaluru and Pune. But now the focus is on this one. Test Cricket is a funny game. We did not play badly against Sri Lanka. We have tried to keep things simple and play our brand of cricket. Whether you are batting first or bowling first, you have to play well. Sodhi and Henry come in for Southee and Santner"

Rohit Sharma | India Captain: "We would have batted as well. Yeah absolutely, we understand we haven't played well. But again gives us another opportunity to come back and looks a good wicket. Hopefully, we can restrict them to as low as possible and then do well with the bat. Right now our focus is on this Test match. On the back of the mind you need to keep in mind about that (WTC), but right now we need to play our best cricket which we haven't this series. Unfortunately, Bumrah is not well and Siraj comes in place of him."
PostMatchCommentary:
Day 1
NZ:- 235(3.58 rpo, 13x4, 6x6) ll IND - 86/4 (4.52 rpo, 10x4, 1x6) 

Day 2
IND - 177/6 (4.35 rpo, 18x4, 4x6) ll NZ -  171/9 (3.93 rpo, 9x4, 7x6)

Day 3
NZ:- 3/1 (1.28 rpo, 0x4, 0x6) ll IND - 121 (4.15 rpo, 11x4, 1x6)  

New Zealand script unprecedented chapter in Test cricket - first-ever 3-0 whitewash of India at home, ending the hosts' 24-year streak without a series sweep. Chasing 147 to get the vital WTC points, India's resistance crumbled at 121, despite Pant's counter-attacking 64.
The match pivoted on crucial phases: New Zealand's resilient 235 after winning a vital toss, India's response earning a slim 28-run lead. Visitors' adventurous 174 in the second innings, perfectly gauging the deteriorating surface, set up the finale.
From 29/5, it became the Pant show - counter-attacking fifty at a strike rate above 100 keeping Indian hopes alive. Phillips' double-strike and Ajaz's final flourish sealed an unprecedented 3-0 whitewash, India's first at home.The stark scoreline (India 0 - New Zealand 3) marks only the second home series whitewash since South Africa's 2-0 in 1999-2000. A result sending shockwaves through World Test Championship calculations, with India's final hopes now precariously placed. 


 Rohit Sharma | India Captain: 
"Losing a series or losing a Test match is never easy. It is something that is not digestible. We didn't play good cricket. New Zealand played better than us. Credit to them. We have to accept that we didn't play the best cricket and made a lot of mistakes. We didn't score enough first innings score in the previous two matches and were always behind in the game. In this game, we had the lead; we were a little ahead, but we failed to capitalize. While chasing a target, we need to have runs on the board. I had that in mind. It didn't come off. And when it doesn't come off, it looks bad. We come up with a certain mindset while batting; if it comes off, it is great, or else it looks really bad. I had specific strategies that didn't work this series. Our cricket wasn't up to par in these conditions, and we're facing those consequences. As I mentioned, our performance wasn't at its best, and that's why we're in this position. Pant, Gill, and Washington demonstrated how to bat on these surfaces - you need to be proactive. We've been playing on similar pitches for three years now. Unfortunately, our tactical approaches didn't succeed this series. I take responsibility for not delivering my best, both as captain and batsman. As a team unit, we fell short."  


Ajaz Patel | Player of the Match:
"Spin bowling is fundamentally about finding your rhythm. When conditions are favorable, you need to seize the opportunity completely. I was feeling confident during the morning session too. After lunch, there was significantly more turn which worked in my favor. My approach was to keep things uncomplicated and try to outthink the batsmen. Regarding the contest with Pant - he's an exceptional batsman who put us under considerable pressure. It required creative thinking and alternative strategies to deal with him." 


Will Young | Player of the Series: 
"Firstly, for the team to come here and win the series, it is huge. To win one game here is so huge, but to come out again and again and win the series with a 3-0 margin is unbelievable. Really proud of the boys. My batting approach was about simplicity. I focus on maintaining a clear mindset and trusting my defensive technique. It's also important to identify scoring opportunities. Like ducks sitting on water, staying calm. We really enjoyed playing together as a team. About taking Kane's number 3 position? Well, let's see what happens in the next series."
 


Tom Latham | New Zealand Captain: 
"Yeah, I'm absolutely ecstatic. Looking back at the series start, the team has performed exceptionally. To achieve this in Mumbai, on a challenging surface for both batting and bowling, is incredibly satisfying. Our success came from adapting to each venue's conditions. In Bengaluru, we had different players stepping up at crucial moments. Last week it was Mitch's performance, and this time Ajaz, who particularly enjoys bowling here in Mumbai. Our approach was about keeping things uncomplicated. This is exactly what we discussed weeks ago - being proactive and understanding India's style while adapting our game accordingly. The team executed well, and I'm proud to be standing here with this result. We believed our runs were sufficient in these conditions. On this wicket, we knew it would be challenging. Each victory is special - the women's World Cup triumph is fantastic, our win here is remarkable, and the Black Caps' rugby success last night makes it a brilliant time for New Zealand sports."

TossDetails: South Africa Won The Toss And Elected To Field
TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Field
CompetitionName: India Tour Of South Africa T20 Series 2024
PreMatchCommentary:
India and South Africa are set for a thrilling four-match T20I series, beginning November 8 at Kingsmead Stadium, Durban. With India riding high as T20 World Champions, thanks to their recent win over South Africa in the finals, the Proteas are keen for redemption on home soil.

Led by the explosive Suryakumar Yadav, India comes in with a six-match winning streak. Despite missing some senior players, they bring young stars like Abhishek Sharma and Rinku Singh, adding depth to their power-packed lineup. South Africa, led by Aiden Markram, fields an almost full-strength squad featuring David Miller and Heinrich Klaasen, making them formidable in familiar conditions.

This series promises exciting matchups: Suryakumar’s strokeplay against South Africa’s pace attack and Miller’s finishing prowess against India’s spinners. With matches across iconic venues in Durban, Gqeberha, Centurion, and Johannesburg, fans can expect a fiercely competitive series as India looks to extend its T20 dominance, while South Africa aims to protect its home pride in what’s sure to be an intense battle.

Head-To-Head in T20Is:
In the 27 games battled between the two teams, India edge over South Africa by 15-11 and one game ended in no-result.

Pitch Report By Shaun Pollock:

An overcast, blustery evening sets the stage for a gripping contest here at Kingsmead. Veteran all-rounder Shaun Pollock notes the hard, true surface is primed to offer pace, bounce and carry - a tantalizing prospect for the quicks with the new ball.

However, the capricious Durban breeze could prove a double-edged sword, potentially aiding the seamers early on, but also allowing the batters to play their strokes confidently. The captain winning the toss faces a crucial decision - capitalize on helpful bowling conditions, or post a challenging first-innings total before the forecast rain arrives later?


Toss:- South Africa have won the toss and decided to bowl first.


Aiden Markram: We will bowl first today. The pitch looks quite good, and since there's been some rain this week, we’re hoping to use any moisture that may still be there to our advantage. It’s also a fantastic chance for the new guys to debut on home turf, and we want them to enjoy every moment of it. We’re a very competitive side, and our discussions have been centered on how we can drive towards positive results

Suryakumar Yadav: We were hoping to bat first. The pitch looks good—much better than the practice one—so our goal is to put up a solid total. The team has made my role easier; everyone plays with a fearless mindset, just like they do for their franchises, and they’ve brought that same energy here.
PostMatchCommentary:

India : 56/1 (9.33 rpo, 6x4, 4x6) || South Africa - 49/3 (8.16 rpo, 6x4, 2x6) 

Middle overs (7-15 Overs) -
India : 111/2 (12.33 rpo, 7x4, 8x6) || South Africa - 65/5 (7.22 rpo, 3x4, 5x6) 

Death overs (16-20 Overs) -
India : 35/5 ( 7 rpo, 4x4, 1x6) || South Africa - 27/2 (9.52 rpo, 1x4, 2x6) 
 

India took a 1-0 lead in the series with a commanding 61-run victory. After being put in to bat, India set a formidable target, reaching 202/8, thanks largely to an impressive century from Sanju Samson. He found solid support from Tilak Varma and Suryakumar Yadav, who chipped in with valuable contributions to keep the momentum going. South Africa's Gerald Coetzee was their standout bowler, claiming 3 wickets.

In pursuit of 203, South Africa struggled from the start and fell short by 61 runs, never really managing to get into the chase. India's bowlers dominated the innings, with Varun and Ravi Bishnoi sharing six wickets equally, each taking three crucial scalps. Heinrich Klaasen managed to top-score for South Africa with 25 runs, but it wasn’t enough to steady their innings. The South African batting lineup crumbled, eventually getting bowled out for 141.

Sanju Samson (Player Of The Match)
I’m really enjoying my time out there in the middle. I’ve been in good form, so I’m making the most of it while it lasts. It all comes down to intent—we’ve been focused on playing aggressively and keeping the team on the front foot. You have to aim for those boundary shots; sometimes they work, sometimes they don’t. This was an important win because South Africa is a strong team, especially at home. We’re thrilled to kick off the series in this way.

Aiden Markram ( South Africa Captain)
The toss didn’t play a huge role today. The new ball had a bit of bounce and movement off the surface, which made things tricky early on. From our perspective, it really came down to our batting—we could have done better in that area.

Suryakumar Yadav (India Captain)
Oh really, I didn’t know that! It’s great, though, that we’ve been sticking to our usual style of play. We haven’t changed much, so I’m pleased with the win. Sanju’s hard work is paying off now—he even kept going for big shots in the 90s, always putting the team first. It’s great to have him with us. Yes, we planned to use spinners against Miller and Klaasen, and they both delivered perfectly. Honestly, it does feel a bit easier (laughs). As I mentioned in the press conference, the team has simplified my job, and everyone understands their roles well.

CompetitionName: India Tour Of South Africa T20 Series 2024
PreMatchCommentary:
India's juggernaut rolls into Gqeberha with the scent of series dominance in their nostrils. After Sanju Samson's masterclass lit up Durban in the opener, the visitors now have their sights set on a commanding 2-0 lead at St George's Park.The Proteas find themselves in familiar troubled waters, their batting lineup still dizzy from the spin web woven by Varun Chakaravarthy and Ravi Bishnoi. But write off Aiden Markram's men at your peril – this fortress of St George's Park has been their happy hunting ground, with three wins from their last four T20Is.South Africa's cavalry arrives in the form of Heinrich Klaasen and David Miller, two explosive game-changers who could turn the tide. Yet, the hosts' Achilles heel against spin remains a concern that needs urgent addressing.Team India, meanwhile, shows no signs of tinkering with their winning formula, though opener Abhishek Sharma's form raises eyebrows. The visitors' batting arsenal looks locked and loaded with Suryakumar Yadav and Tilak Varma in murderous form.As the Sunday showdown beckons, one burning question remains: Can the Proteas solve their spin puzzle, or will India's tweakers once again prove to be their nemesis? 


 

Pitch Report | Ashwell Prince & Shaun Pollock:
"It’s overcast here in Gqeberha, and there’s a chance of rain. The pitch looks slightly different from the usual surface, with a bit more grass cover than we’re accustomed to. The conditions have changed slightly with the cloud cover and recent rain, which will likely favour the seamers. The grass should help the seam bowlers get some movement, and though it’s firm and solid, batters should feel encouraged too. There isn’t expected to be much spin tonight, but this venue often holds something for the spinners despite appearances. South Africa struggled against spin in the first T20I, so it’ll be interesting to see if that plays a role here. The surface is hard underneath, meaning the ball should carry nicely through to the keeper.It looks like a good pitch to the eye, with something for both batters and seamers. The key question: will India’s two spinners enjoy these conditions? With rain looming, teams might prefer to bowl first." 



TOSS UPDATE: South Africa Won the Toss and Elected to field 

Aiden Markram | South Africa Captain:
"We’re opting to bowl first with a bit of rain around. Hopefully, there’ll be some assistance for the seamers early on. Reeza Hendricks is back in, replacing Patrick Kruger. For us, it’s about winning those 240 balls of cricket, and staying focused on playing well rather than worrying about the result. Hopefully, the outcome will be in our favor."  

Suryakumar Yadav | India Captain:
"We achieved what we set out to in the first T20I. We wanted to bat first, make a statement, and stick to our brand of cricket, so I’m happy with how things went. Every game teaches you something, and we want to build on those good habits—just play our game, enjoy the little things. We’re going with the same XI, no changes."
PostMatchCommentary:

Middle overs (7-15 Overs) -

Death overs (16-20 Overs) -
India : 38/1 ( 7.6 rpo, 4x4, 2x6) || South Africa - 44/4 (11 rpo, 7x4, 2x6)  
 

In a gripping low-scorer, South Africa clawed their way back into the series, chasing down India's modest 124 with 3 wickets in hand and an over to spare, leveling the contest 1-1. Opting to bowl, the Proteas' disciplined attack stifled India from the outset. Early dismissals of Samson, Sharma and Yadav left the visitors reeling at 15/3. Pandya's gritty 39* lifted India to 124/6, but it seemed under par. The South African chase stumbled as spin wizard Chakravarthy spun a web, his 5/17 leaving the hosts 86/7. However, local hero Stubbs (47*) and Coetzee engineered a vital 42-run stand to take SA over the line. Despite Chakravarthy's heroics, India's pacers couldn't close it out, allowing the SA tail to hold their nerve. This absorbing encounter sets up a mouthwatering decider, with both sides showcasing resilience and match-winners. South Africa's bowlers first set the tone, before Stubbs' composure and Chakravarthy's brilliance provided the drama in a low-scoring thriller. The series is evenly poised, primed for an enthralling finale 

Tristan Stubbs | Player of the Match:
"We were lucky that the required rate never got out of hand. I aimed to get around 30 off the last three overs, and with some help from the dew and Coetzee’s big shots, we managed to cross the line. Playing here, with the crowd behind us, is always special. Now that it’s 1-1, we have everything to play for in the next match." 

Suryakumar Yadav | India Captain:
"We always back whatever total we put up, and I reminded the team to fight till the end, regardless of the score. In T20, defending 125 isn’t ideal, but I’m proud of how we bowled. Varun Chakaravarthy’s five-wicket haul was remarkable, especially under pressure defending a low total. He’s worked hard, and it showed today. We’re heading to Jo’burg with the series tied 1-1, and it promises to be exciting cricket." 

Aiden Markram | South Africa Captain:
"I thought we bowled well today; the bowlers stuck to the plans, and I’m proud of them. Our batting wasn’t great as we lost wickets in clusters, which made things tricky. Thankfully, my finger’s doing fine. Hats off to Coetzee and Stubbs—they came off a break and showed great hunger. To deliver such a performance against India is always satisfying. Levelling the series going into the Highveld is fantastic, even if it wasn’t the way we ideally wanted to get over the line."

TossText: Won The Toss And Elected To Field
CompetitionName: India Tour Of South Africa T20 Series 2024
PreMatchCommentary:
The T20I series between India and South Africa moves to SuperSport Park, Centurion, perfectly poised at 1-1 after two contrasting encounters that showcase the quality of both sides.

India's commanding performance at Kingsmead featured Sanju Samson's masterful century (107 off 50), demonstrating their batting firepower. The spin duo of Varun Chakravarthy and Ravi Bishnoi has added another dimension to their bowling arsenal, with Chakravarthy's exceptional spells (3/25 and 5/17) highlighting India's versatility in different conditions.

South Africa showed their resilience at St George's Park, with Tristan Stubbs' composed 47* leading a calculated chase. The Proteas' pace battery, spearheaded by Gerald Coetzee, has consistently challenged the batters, while Keshav Maharaj's economic bowling has provided crucial control.

The series now shifts to Centurion's pace-friendly terrain, where batting historically flourishes at 9.46 runs per over. Both teams have momentum to build upon - India's sophisticated spin strategy and dynamic batting lineup, matched against South Africa's pace prowess and home conditions advantage.

With the addition of Lutho Sipamla to the Proteas squad, the stage is set for an enthralling contest between two sides showcasing cricket's next generation of talent. 

TOSS UPDATE: South Africa won the Toss and Elected to Field 

Aiden Markram | South Africa Captain:
"We'll bowl first again. The wicket looks good, and it tends to play better under lights, so we're sticking with that plan. Our last game wasn’t our best, but it’s a positive that we still managed to come out on top. It’s about finding rhythm and time in the middle, and we back our players to perform. We’ve made one change: Nqaba Peter is out, and Lutho Sipamla comes in." 

Suryakumar Yadav | India Captain:
"We’ve done well batting first in the last two games, and we wanted to put runs on the board anyway. The boys have shown up with clear plans and executed them well, so I’m happy with how they’re performing. The message is simple—stick to your skills, go out there, and enjoy yourselves. They’ve really made my job easier. We’ve made one change: Ramandeep Singh is making his debut, while Avesh Khan sits out. Avesh has been great for us, but we needed to make room, so Ramandeep gets his chance."
PostMatchCommentary:

India clinched a thrilling 11-run win over South Africa, taking a 2-1 lead in the series. Batting first, India posted a formidable 219/6 in 20 overs. Tilak Varma was the standout performer, scoring an unbeaten 107 off 56 balls, including eight fours and seven sixes. Abhishek Sharma supported with a brisk 50 off 25 balls. Despite wickets falling at regular intervals, India maintained a high scoring rate, aided by Ramandeep Singh’s quick 15 off 6 balls towards the end.

South Africa’s chase was spirited, especially with Marco Jansen blazing his way to a 17-ball 54, smashing four fours and five sixes. Heinrich Klaasen added a swift 41 off 22 balls, keeping the visitors in the hunt. However, India’s bowlers held their nerve, with Arshdeep Singh taking 3/37 in his 4 overs, including the crucial wicket of Jansen in the final overs.

While Hardik Pandya and Axar Patel chipped in with a wicket each, it was Arshdeep’s breakthrough at critical moments that sealed the game for India. The hosts now lead the series 2-1, putting them in a strong position heading into the next match. 


Tilak Varma | Player of the Match:
"Yes, I’m fine! The catch was tricky under the lights, but I’m doing well now. Honestly, I can’t describe it—it was a dream to score a hundred for my country, and I’m really happy. All credit to our captain, Suryakumar Yadav, for giving me the opportunity at number three. He encouraged me before the game, saying I had the potential for this role. Huge thanks to him for the support." 


Aiden Markram | South Africa Captain:
"Really proud of the team, especially with the contributions from the middle and lower middle order. Here in Centurion, when the middle order steps up, it usually sets you up for a strong finish. Once a partnership builds, things can escalate quickly. At this venue, you almost expect to chase totals down—it becomes an over-by-over battle. Marco was fantastic in the last over; if you keep doing the right things, success follows. The batters can take confidence from this, and the bowlers will look to fine-tune their skills before we head to Joburg." 

Suryakumar Yadav | India Captain: 
"As captain, I felt we played the brand of cricket we set out to play. We’ve been talking about playing the way we do for our franchises or state teams, and I believe staying clear-minded is crucial. Watching our batters perform like they did today made my job so much easier, and it feels like we’re moving in the right direction as a team. The energy, aggression, and intent on display were really satisfying to see. Tilak Varma actually came to my room before the game and asked if he could bat at number 3, and I’m really happy for him and his family that it worked out so well."

TossDetails: India Won The Toss And Elected To Bat

PreMatchCommentary:
Welcome to the Live coverage of the 4th and final T20 in this series between India and South Africa from The Wanderers, Johannesburg. India, leading 2-1, look to cap off their outstanding T20I Campaign with another victory.The visitors have found different heroes throughout - Samson's ton in the opener, Chakravarthy's five-fer in the second, and Tilak Varma's maiden T20I century in Centurion steering them to an unassailable lead.Despite captain Markram winning all three tosses, South Africa hasn't converted advantages into victories. Their batting lacks consistency while bowling discipline remains a concern. Still seeking their first bilateral T20I series win in eight attempts, the Proteas aim to level the series 2-2.The Wanderers' pace-friendly conditions could favor the hosts' fast bowling arsenal. However, India's new aggressive batting approach, evident throughout 2024, makes them favorites even on bouncy tracks. 

TOSS UPDATE: India Won The Toss and Elected to Bat  

Suryakumar Yadav | India Captain:
"We’re batting first again, as we’ve been doing well with that approach and want to keep the momentum. Our plan is clear: put runs on the board and defend strongly. The boys have performed well, and I’m confident everyone is ready for the challenge with the series on the line. No changes to the playing XI." 

Aiden Markram | South Africa Captain:
"We were leaning towards batting but weren’t entirely sure, so it wasn’t the worst toss to lose. Our focus today is to put together a complete performance in all three departments, something we haven’t fully achieved yet. We’re getting closer to that 100% mark. Playing at the Bullring is always exciting, and while we can only level the series, coming back from 1-0 down gives us confidence. That said, execution will be key. We’re sticking with the same team."
PostMatchCommentary:
